title: amazing true story inspired classic
story: NewsAmazing true story that inspired the classic book Robinson CrusoeThe reality is every bit as stuning as the classic novelShareByJames Moore:,  APR NewsThe true story that inspired Robinson Crusoe is just as amazing as the book "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailItaposs inspired films, plays, television series and captivated millions of readers. The novel, often hailed as the first true English novel, is now  years old. An instant classic, it has been translated into hundreds of languages and inspired Gulliveraposs Travels and The Swiss Family Robinson. Hollywood has also taken Daniel Defoeaposs lead and used it as the basis for hit films like Cast Away, starring Tom Hanks. But the work of fiction is actually based on an amazing true story.    And the events that proved irrestitable to Defoe are every bit as incredible as those within the pages of the novel. Scottish sailor Alexander Selkirk was a real le castaway was every bit as dramatic as Crusoeaposs. Defoe is even said to have met Selkirk, already a celebrity thanks to his seafaring escapades, at a Bristol inn, before penning his book. And while the author never confirmed that Selkirk was the model for Crusoe, the similarities between the two tales have led historians to believe that this is just where Defoe got his big idea. In The Le And Strange Surprising Adventures Of Robinson Crusoe of York, Mariner, Defoeaposs character runs away to sea and is shipwrecked on a Caribbean island.    As sole survivor, he is forced to fend for himself. He recovers weapons and tools from the wreck, then slowly learns to cope - building a hut and learning to hunt. In time he even grows wheat, makes pottery and raises goats, while creating a calendar out of notches on a piece of wood. After famously encountering Friday and teaching him English, Crusoe is eventually rescued after nearly three decades on the island. Just  years before the rip-roaring read hit the shelves, Alexander Selkirk had been marooned on the uninhabited island of Más a Tierra  miles off the coast of Chile in the South Pacic Ocean. The roguish son of a cobbler, from Lower Largo, Fe, the young Selkirk was often in trouble and fled to sea as a teenager. He soon became a buccaneer, joining William Dampieraposs privateers sanctioned by the British government to attack Spanish vessels. But in September , while sailing master of a ship called the Cinque Ports, Selkirk fell out with its skipper Captain Thomas Stradling, who had ignored his warnings that the shipaposs worm ridden timbers had made it unseaworthy. Fearing the craft was about to sink, he demanded to be let off on the island and was duly abandoned on the mountainous  squaremile piece of land, with only a musket, cooking pot and kne along with some bedding, cheese, jam, a flask of rum and a Bible. Selkirk had expected fellow sailors to follow his lead, but when they didnapost, immediately regretted his rash decision.However, the ruthless Stradling wouldnapost let him back on board the ship.  He would spend the next four-and-a-half years on the island.At first Selkirk stayed on the shore forlornly scanning the horizon for passing vessels, but was soon driven inland by wailing two-tonne elephant seals. As the reality of his situation dawned Selkirk showed incredible fortitude, just like Crusoe. He survived by hunting feral goats, even learning how to chase them down on foot, while harvesting wild turnips and cabbage too.Selkirk built a hut out of pepper trees for shelter, fashioned a new kne out of old barrel hoops and domesticated feral cats to help ward off the rats that attacked him at night. Eventually Selkirkaposs feet were so hardened by island le that he didnapost need shoes and he made new clothes from goat skins, while singing to keep himself occupied or finding refuge in reading the Bible just as Crusoe does in Defoeaposs book. While Defoeaposs character has to battle man-eating natives and pirates, Selkirk had equally narrow escapes.He was once badly injured in a fall from a clf and, when a ship did arrive, it turned out to be Spanish.Fearing capture, or death, Selkirk successfully hid up a tree while evading enemy sailors who urinated beneath it. Eventually, on February , , an English ship, The Duke, anchored off the island for supplies. Its captain, Woodes Rogers, found Selkirk barely able to remember how to talk. Yet by now the marooned man had become so adept at survival that he was able to help feed and restore Rogersapos ailing crew who had been suffering from scurvy. Indeed Rogers was so impressed that he gave Selkirk the post of second mate aboard the Duke. In the book, after being rescued, Robinson Crusoe discovers his estates have made him a wealthy in his absence. Selkirk himself ed to Britain in  having made plenty of booty after resuming his career as a privateer.  It also turned out that he had been right about the Cinque Ports, which had sunk shortly after leaving Selkirk behind.Its crew had either been killed or ended up languishing in Spanish prisons.By the time Defoe came to publish Robinson Crusoe, the story of Selkirkaposs amazing survival, against the odds, had already been made public in several accounts. There were other stories of castaways at the time that Defoe may have drawn on, but it seems that Selkirk was the most obvious basis for his hero. In , the connection between Selkirk and the novel came full circle when the Chilean government renamed the island where he had been stranded as Isla Robinson Crusoe - proving the international appeal of Defoeaposs story.  Indeed we have become obsessed with the idea of the lone castaway ever since the book came out on April , . Itaposs a theme on which Radio aposs Desert Island Discs has capitalised - where celebrities choose music and items theyaposd take with them to make the solitude bearable. And there have been other thrilling real-le tales of castaways to intrigue and fascinate us. Just like Crusoe, who goes back to his island for more adventures in Defoeaposs little known sequel, Selkirk never settled into le on land and later enlisted in the Royal Navy.He died at sea from yellow fever in . After hisfrom isolation he had once said: I am now worth  pounds, but shall never be so happy, as when I was not worth a farthing.

title: bride spends 7800 nose job
story: NewsBride spends £, on nose job to give her extra confidence for wedding dayLeanne Armstrong had always felt self-conscious about her nose and didnt want to worry about it on her special dayShareCommentsByLisa HutchinsonReporter:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsLeanne and Jake tied the knot at Newton Hall in Northumberland "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A bride-to-be who had been insecure about her nose from a young age had plastic surgery in the run up to her wedding day. Leanne Armstrong forked out £, for a nose job to give her extra confidence as she walked down the aisle.She had been worried about her wedding pictures and said sheaposd always particularly felt self-conscious of her side profile. But after going through the surgery, the -year-old tied the knot with fiancé Jake and posed for the photos without a care in the world. The happy couple were pleased with the photographs of their special day.   Leanne told Chronicle Live : “My nose has always been an insecurity of mine from a young age and I always felt particularly self-conscious of my side profile.“Having surgery felt like a massive sense of relief.It’s the simple things that might seem trivial to some people but that would make me feel anxious like meeting new people or not worrying about where you stand for a photo.” Leanne, of Croxdale, near County Durham, added: “The photographs really played on my mind. I know it seems small but I just didn’t want to feel the way I had most of my le around a camera, on the happiest day of my le.” Leanne and Jake met in  as they both went to the same gym and they tied the knot at Newton Hall in Northumberland.    The project manager added: “I felt comfortable, confident and didn’t worry at any moment throughout the day when people were taking photos. We just had the best day enjoying our time together, and the photos were incredible - we were so happy with them.” Leanne researched ious surgeons in the UK before choosing Dr Andrea Giannitrapani at MYA Cosmetic Surgery in Newcastle and had the operation at the First Trust Hospital in Preston. She added: “Although my nose was an insecurity of mine, I consciously tried to never let it stop me from doing anything. Had I not had surgery, nothing about the wedding day would have been dferent - but I would have felt dferent, and I would have known. That’s what matters. “I told my friends and family and they were all really supportive and happy for me as they all knew how insecure I had been about my nose for so long.”  Management consultant Jake, , said: “Leanne has always been absolutely beautul regardless of the surgery. But I knew how much this meant to her and the real dference has been how much more visibly confident and comfortable she is.” A spokesman for MYA Cosmetic Surgery, said: “It is not uncommon for men and women who have been considering a Rhinoplasty procedureto go ahead with surgery in the run up to their big day. A wedding day is often one of those defining trigger moments where a patients consideration of surgery based on the insecurities they’ve had all their lives, really becomes apparent. “The likelihood is that they would still have gone ahead with the procedure at some point in their lives but something like this often makes patients realise how important it is to them. “However, our duty of care to each patient is to ensure that their decision is fully informed and that surgery will have a signicantly positive impact on the state of their physical, mental and social well-being for the long term, not just their wedding day.”

title: girl put isolation school over
story: NewsGirl put in isolation at school over Manchester Arena bombing tribute tattooKia Hiltons father has slammed the schools decision to place his -year-old daughter in isolation for three weeks and to prevent her attending GCSE revision classesShareCommentsByEmma Gill:,  APR NewsKia, , was placed in isolation after a member of staff noticed a tattoo of bee behind her ear "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad has slammed a school for placing his daughter in isolation for three weeks after a member of staff spotted her Manchester Arena bombing tribute tattoo.Kia Hilton, , was at the Ariana Grande concert on May , , where  people died when a suicide bomber launched an attack.Along with thousands of other Mancunians, Kia went on to have a bee tattooed on to her body as a symbol of the cityaposs courage and unity in the wake of the attack.Despite being under the  age limit for tattoos, with her parentsapos permission, Kia chose to have the small bee tattoo behind her ear, similar to the one Ariana Grande herself had done, reports the Manchester Evening News .Although Kia has had the tattoo since November last year, her dad says a teacher at her school, Hyde Community College, only spotted it earlier this week - and put the teenager in isolation. Brian says they got a call from school to say she would be in isolation for Kiaaposs remaining three weeks and would not be able to attend GCSE revision classes before and after school.    He said: Itaposs horrendous the way they have treated her. Itaposs not just the isolation, but the fact theyaposre stopping her doing her extra GCSE revision. Weaposve both struggled since the bomb, weaposve been on medication since and we donapost even go out on our own. Things like Bonfire Night are awful. Kia will be in the corner of the room curled up in a ball because of all the bangs. Kia got blown to the floor with the force of the bomb and the ambulance was called to my address afterwards because as soon as we got out of the car I passed out. It was just the trauma of the things we saw. Honestly we have tried everything to try and forget those memories but the slightest thing, a bang or crowds, just brings it all back.    The -year-old, who lives five minutesapos from the school in Busheyfield Close, Hyde, said he doesnapost understand why it has only just become an issue then, when the tattoo was done last year. The dad-of-six said: Kia has really long hair and you honestly canapost see the tattoo unless you look for it. Itaposs exactly the same as Ariana Grandeaposs and is just something she wanted to do. Youaposd think the school would realise the special circumstances for her having it. We know sheaposs not  and Iaposd always said be in your s before having one, especially girls as I think they can end up regretting them, but in these circumstances we allowed it. Kia told us: I was just walking down the stairs at school and one of the teachers was looking at me and asked what I was doing, saying it looked like I was trying to hide earrings. When I said I didnapost have earrings in, he saw the tattoo and started shouting, saying it was against school rules. If I hadnapost have been walking near him he wouldnapost have even seen it.    Other teachers have seen it before and made comments like aposwell you canapost exactly take it off can youapos. Itaposs not like itaposs been any sort of distraction, you canapost even see it under my hair. After the M.E.N requested a response from the school, Kiaaposs family received a phone call telling them she was able toto normal classes from Friday morning - and do her extra revision classes - but with a plaster over the tattoo. A spokesperson for Hyde Community College said: “The school provided extensive support for pupils affected by the Manchester Arena bombing, including counselling. title: how young mum 25 saved
story: NewsHow young mum, , saved for first home in just TWO YEARS while caring for sonRia Alice, , managed to save enough for the deposit for the Nottingham property with no help from the bank of mum and dadShareCommentsByPesala BandaraBradley Jolly:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsRia Alice has told how she and Reivan Grfin budgeted to buy a house with son Markus "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum has revealed how she saved up the deposit for a £, home in just two years. Ria Alice, , purchased the three-bedroom house after making little sacrices while caring for four-year-old son Markus. The healthcare assistant was just  when she and boyfriend Reivan Grfin bought their first home in Nottingham - with no financial help from her parents. My motto was aposlive like you’re brokeapos so I got rid of all my online subscriptions and stopped getting takeaway coffees for example, inspirational Ria said. But the mother-of-one still enjoyed a healthy social le and managed to treat little Markus. She added: I never missed out on days out with Markus. We found local activities like Easter Egg hunts and Halloween trails that were just £ for admission or sometimes even free.    Even when I was saving, I managed to carry on enjoying a social le simply by visiting my friends for a cuppa rather than going out to a restaurant for dinner.   With a bit of work and research, it’s definitely possible for young people to get on the housing ladder. The social media influencer began saving when she was  and found enough for the £, deposit in July . Ria, Reivan and Markus moved in with her mum in the interim and she assessed all her outgoings.    Ria continued: Moving back in with my mum gave me a massive opportunity to be able to save up for a mortgage deposit. I was very lucky to be able to do this as it meant not having to pay rent or other household bills where. I also worked extra night shts which sometimes meant looking after our son Markus the next day with absolutely no sleep. It was definitely a killer. But you have to remember that these little sacrices won’t last forever. They’re temporary and mean you can make a better le for you and your family.    It all pays off in the end. The day we bought our first home was genuinely one the happiest days of my le. I was over the moon. Childcare was important so I could go to work. But my monthly subscriptions to Hayu, Tidal and Beauty Box weren’t. I cut out that spending and immediately had an extra £ per month to save. Every penny counts. And for mums who want to carry on treating their kids alongside saving, there are so many family-friendly, local activities to do for free or for as little as a quid.    The Victorian terraced house needed some work doing it when the couple bought it. But resourceful Ria and Reivan, a -year-old delivery driver, also budgeted on the renovations. I’m inspired to keep renovating properties now and moving up the housing ladder. It’s a project we absolutely love doing, she added. RIA’S TOP TIPS FOR GETTING ON THE HOUSING LADDER MOVE BACK IN WITH YOUR PARENTS: If you can, move back into your parents’ house or your grandparents – anyone who can accommodate you to cut out rent payments whilst saving. It makes a huge dference. WORK EXTRA: Whether it’s getting a second job, doing extra shts or joining an agency, find a way to increase your income and save more money. Once you get that extra salary in your bank account, put it straight into your savings. MANAGE YOUR OUTGOINGS AND SEE WHAT YOU CAN SACRIFICE: Make a list of your expenditure and ide into a list of what is important and what isn’t. Do you need that Hayu subscription  Can you reduce your car insurance  It’s amazing what you can save by re-evaluating your outgoings and getting rid of any non-essential costs! LIVE LIKE YOU’RE BROKE: This is my favourite tip for anyone wanting to get on the property ladder! Live like you have no money to go on that random meal out or on holiday. Only go out on special occasions and only buy what you need not what you want.

Dog walkers raised the alarm when they made the grisly discovery in New Waltham, Lincolnshire, on Thursday morningThere are fears that more body parts may be nearby as Humberside Police widen their search area to include two large fields bordering the path and a stream, GrimsbyLive reports.   It is understood the foot and lower leg, which were found along an old railway line, are that of a female. A police cordon has surrounded the scene since Thursday as police try to unravel the mystery.    The parish councilaposs chairman warned locals that a body or more body parts could be somewhere in the village, telling residents to be village and know where their children are at all times. A man who lives near the scene said of one of the dog walkers: She is still traumatised by what she found. It looked like a small foot around a size four and was a womanaposs foot. The man said the body part may have been taken to the path by an animal. He added: We can only guess. story: NewsWorlds most fertile woman had  kids by  - and shes raising them aloneMariam Nabatanzi , from Uganda, has a rare medical condition and had  children by the time she was ShareCommentsByElias BiryabaremaJane Lavender:,  APR Updated:,  APR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video mariam-nabatanzi-one-highest-birth-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, options :, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, options :, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The worldaposs most fertile woman has had an incredible  children - and now has to raise her massive brood on her own. Mariam Nabatanzi had her record number of babies by the time she was just  and all with the same father. Now , Mariam has had three sets of quadruplets, four sets of triplets and six sets of twins.Sadly, her husband walked out on her three years ago and she is now solely responsible for her huge family. Mariam, from Uganda, was married aged just  to her then -year-old husband.    Her first set of twins came along just a year later. Mariamaposs le has been marred by tragedy and she and all of her children are forced to live in four cramped homes built from cement bricks with a corrugated iron roof. They are surrounded by coffee fields. After her first sets of twins were born, Nabatanzi went to a doctor who told her she had unusually large oies. He advised her that birth control like pills might cause health problems, so the children kept coming.    Large families are common in Africa with women in Uganda giving birth to . children in average, one of the highest birth rates on the continent according to the World Bank. But even in Uganda Mariamaposs family is considered huge. By the time she was  Mariam had  children and, desperate, went back to see her doctor in a bid to stop her having any more Once again, she was advised to keep getting pregnant because he oy count was so high. Her last pregnancy, two and a half years ago, had complications.    She gave birth to her sixth set of twins, but sadly one of them died during the labour. Then her husband - often absent for long stretches - abandoned her. His name is now a family curse and Mariam swears whenever she refers to him. She said: I have grown up in tears, my man has passed me through a lot of suffering. All my time has been spent looking after my children and working to earn some money.  And with so many mouths to feed, Mariam will turn her hand to anything. She has worked as a hairdresser and an event decorator. Mariam collects and sells scrap metal, brews local gin and sells herbal medicine. Most of her wages are spent on food to feed her huge family, medical care, clothes and school fees to ensure her brood has the best start in le. On a grimy wall in one room of her home hang proud portraits of some of her children graduating from school, gold tinsel around their necks.  Her eldest child, Ivan Kibuka, had to drop out of school to help raise the family. The -year-old said: Mum is overwhelmed, the work is crushing her, we help where we can, like in cooking and washing, but she still carries the whole burden for the family. I feel for her. Mariamaposs mother walked out on her, her father and her five siblings three days after she was born. After her father remarried, her stepmother poisoned the five older children with crushed glass mixed in their food. They all died.  Mariam says she only escaped because she was visiting a relative. She added: I was seven years old then, too young to even understand what death actually meant. I was told by relatives what had happened. This harrowing tragedy sparked her desire for a huge family, although she originally hoped for six children. Providing a home for  youngsters is a constant challenge.  Twelve of the children sleep on metal bunk beds with thin mattresses in one small room with grime-caked walls. In the other rooms, children pile onto shared mattresses while the others sleep on the dirt floor. Older children help look after the young ones and everyone helps with chores like cooking. A single day can require  kilograms of maize flour, Mariam says. Fish or meat are rare treats.

story: Long-serving defender Andy Considine is set to sign a two-year contract extension tying him Aberdeen until summer .It is understood the new contract will also include the option of another year.Considine, , had triggered a clause in his current contract by meeting an appearance threshold that earned him another year-long deal.However, the defender had been locked in talks as to theand terms of a contract.They have reached a compromise with Considine set to pen the new deal.Now into his th season in the Dons first team, Considine is closing in on a th appearance.Securing Considine will be a timely boost for boss Derek McInnes, who has admitted he faces the busiest transfer window of his six years at the club this summer.Captain Graeme Shinnie’s contract expires at the end of the season and he looks set to move on with Derby County leading the race to sign the midfielder.Winger Gary Mackay-Steven also has a contract set to expire in the summer and has been targeted by MLS side New York City.Centre-back Mark Reynolds has signed a pre-contract with Dundee United, the club he is on loan at.Deals for keeper Tomas Cerny and defender Greg Halford run out at the end of the season.Loan agreements for Greg Stewart , Dom Balland James Wilsonwill also end next month.McInnes has been in talks with Ball regarding a permanent deal as his contract at parent club Rotherham is set to expire.The Dons boss was also keen to secure Stewart – who will be a free agent in the summer – on a permanent deal, but Rangers look set to land him.

title: aberdeen dancers gear up for grand prix
story: Aberdeen dancers are hoping they’ll be in pole position to rub shoulders with Formula One stars after being invited to perform at the British Grand Prix.The  pupils from the Sharon Gill Dance School will show off their skills at the Silverstone circuit on July .They will join around  other dancers from across the UK for a special performance before the qualying round. vw, px"  Dance teacher Sharon Gill, who runs classes at the Hanover Community Centre, said organisers of the event got in touch with her after seeing a video of the girls performing in Inverness.She said: “I don’t think they have seen something like us before. There is going to be an argument between the girls who is going to get a photo with Lewis Hamilton first.“They are so excited about celebrity spotting.“I have seen pictures from previous years and there were pictures with all the drivers.“We dance at pm and the qualying race is at pm and I think the drivers just hang about afterwards.“We are dancing on the Saturday, which is the qualying day so we would be more likely to see celebrities.”The girls – who are between the ages of  and  – will dance a routine choreographed by the event’s organisers and is expected to be a mix of jazz and gymnastics.Sharon said: “We don’t know what the routine will be but the organisers will be up to teach us for three days at the end of May.“The girls are very excited, but also very nervous because they will dancing in front of thousands – I don’t even want to know how many people are going to be there.”Sharon said the families of the dancers are almost as excited as the girls.“We need a certain amount of chaperones and I think there has been a battle between the dads to see who can go,” she added.The dance school has been raising money to pay for the trip to Silverstone.Sharon said: “This is definitely not something we would miss – I mean, we’ll be dancing at the grand prix.“The girls have to pay £ to go, but as part of that they get taught the routine, the costume and they get to watch the races.“Also, there is entertainment and it was just announced that Craig David is headlining, which they are very excited about.”To pay for travel and accommodation, they have managed to raise around £,, however there are still fundraising events to come that will hopefully boost that number.A charity race will take place on May  at The White Cockade in Torry from .pm while a fun dance event will take place on June  at Cairncry Community Centre at .pm.To request tickets or to sponsor the dance event email sharongilldance@hotmail

title: aberdeens union terrace gardens revamp start in summer
story: Work to transform Aberdeen#s Union Terrace Gardens will start this summer after a contractor was appointed.Balfour Beatty has been chosen to carry out the £. million works on the historic gardens.The plan will see the space transformed into an #inclusive st Century space# while #enhancing UTG#s heritage features#.LDA design, the firm behind London’s Olympic Park, unveiled their designs for the park in .The flagship project was originally due to be completed by July but had been knocked back until .The transformation of the park includes creating shop and cafe spaces in the arches, and installing water features and community gardens, with work expected to take between  and  months to complete.Council co-Leader Councillor Douglas Lumsden said: “With the selection of Balfour Beatty as contractor, the job of turning the vision for Union Terrace Gardens into reality is about to start in earnest.“This is a moment for celebration right across Aberdeen.“The investment we’re making is transforming our city and the benefits will be felt throughout the region. Generations to come can share in the rewards.”Hector MacAulay, Balfour Beatty’s regional managing director of Scotland and Ireland, said: “We are looking forward to working with Aberdeen City Council to transform the historic Union Terrace Gardens, which on completion will signicantly contribute to the Council’s City Centre Masterplan.“Our construction expertise coupled with our experience in regenerating public spaces makes us ideally positioned to deliver the three new pavilions and sympathetically upgrade this much-loved historic space which will benefit the local community and visitors alike for years to come.”SNP Group Leader, Councillor Stephen Flynn said: “I am sure the people of Aberdeen will be at a total loss as to how the administration can justy spending almost £ million on Union Terrace Gardens when they are continuing to make severe cuts to services across the city.“Project costs have soared by at least £ million since  and it is now certain that the gardens will be delivered two years late – what a complete shambles.”

title: chance to have name etched on aberdeen oor wullie sculpture
story: People are being offered the chance to be immortalised on a unique Oor Wullie sculpture in Aberdeen – all to raise money for charity.Organisers of Oor Wullie’s Big Bucket Trail are offering members of the public the chance to have their name, or that of a loved one, etched in a specially designed Oor Wullie statue which will be gracing the city in the coming months.The sculpture, designed by artist Traci Moss, depicts Oor Wullie as the furry mascot for children’s charity the ARCHIE Foundation, with its trademark white bunny in his arms.A donation of £ is all that is required to have your name etched on the special sculpture. vw, px"  The proceeds of the sale will go to the ARCHIE Foundation – the official charity of the Royal Aberdeen Children’s Hospital, Tayside Children’s Hospital and the Highland Children’s Unit at Raigmore Hospital in Inverness.Ms Moss is putting the finishing touches to the design, which can be found in the Oor Wullie Big Bucket Trail shop on the upper floor of the Bon Accord Centre, before it is unveiled to the public next month.The unique sculpture will be one of  to be found on the Bucket Trail across Scotland.Jamie Smith, fundraising manager for the ARCHIE Foundation, said: “Oor Wullie’s Big Bucket Trail is going to be a fantastic event which I’m sure people across Grampian will get behind.“Your name on Oor Wullie will be a permanent reminder that you have helped sick children in Grampian.“What better way to get people involved than to have their name on one of the sculptures ”Aberdeen is one of five cities taking part in the free art trail, with other sculptures set to appear on the streets of Inverness, Dundee, Edinburgh and Glasgow.The trail will culminate in a series of farewell events in each of the participating cities.The unique statues will eventually be auctioned off following the trail.The money raised through the trail will go to three children’s charities throughout Scotland – the ARCHIE Foundation, Edinburgh’s Children’s Hospital Charity and the Glasgow Children’s Hospital Charity and will help raise vital funds for the children these charities support.The Oor Wullie Bucket Trail  is set to run from June  through to August .Anyone who wants their name, or that of someone close to them, on the statue, can visit the Bon Accord shop or the ARCHIE office at the Royal Aberdeen Children’s Hospital.Alternatively, people can pay online at justgiving campaign AberdeensWullieIf you would like to find out more about the Big Bucket Trail oryou are interested in sponsoring the trail, email jamie@archiefoundation.org.uk.

title: national honours for evening express reporters
story: The Evening Express was celebrating today after tasting glory at a prestigious awards ceremony.Aberdeen’s best-selling newspaper was successful in three categories at the th Scottish Press Awards in Glasgow.The EE and three of its reporters were shortlisted for awards at a black-tie event last night.The glittering ceremony was held at the DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel Glasgow Central, and was attended by around  journalists and others involved in the newspaper industry.Dale Haslam, the paper’s crime and investigations reporter, was crowned Local Weekly Reporter of the Year, while sports reporter Callum Law took home the Local Weekly Sports Writer of the Year gong.Political reporter Adele Merson was named runner-up in the Political Journalist of the Year category – the only woman to make the shortlist – and was also runner-up in the Local Weekly Reporter of the Year award.Evening Express editor Craig Walker said: “Even before the ceremony took place, it was a successful occasion for us.“It was great to have five opportunities to win, so taking home four trophies is brilliant.“The team do a great job delivering fantastic features and great exclusives on a regular basis, and it’s wonderful to see that recognised at a national level. The awards are very much deserved.”Austin Lafferty, chairman of the judges for the Scottish Press Awards, said: “The press and media industry continues to change. The new model is a multi-, fast-moving online offering to targeted audiences, but traditional newspapers are not dying – they are re-forging successful ways of presenting news, analysis, features and lestyle material.“One thing’s for sure from a judging perspective – the quality of output has never been higher.”Dale revealed how the Scottish Prison Service had shut down a Facebook page belonging to a man who had been convicted of trying to kill three police officers.He also told how Snapchat had fixed a flaw that let people track messages that have been sent from or near schools and tracked down a man accused of killing an Aberdeen dad in  who was never prosecuted.Adele, who was also shortlisted for Political Journalist of the Year in , broke the news of former Aberdeen City Council spin doctor Takki Sulaiman receiving a £, pay-off from the local authority.Transport Secretary Michael Matheson also admitted in an interview with Adele that contractors hadn’t been straight with Government about the construction of the AWPR and she also revealed how the city council had appointed an employment consultant amid job role cuts.Adele was also nominated in the Local Weekly Reporter of the Year category, alongside Dale.Her highlights included revealing how an anti-Kingsford stadium group created a fake spokesman and a heartbreaking interview with the mum of a boy who fell from a block of flats and had to have half his skull removed.Meanwhile, Callum exclusively revealed Cove Rangers’ star striker Mitch Megginson had turned down the opportunity join a Premiership team in order to remain with the Balmoral Stadium side.He also told how discussions had been had about adding another tier to the Scottish football leagues – an issue of local and national signicance, while his story of Dons full-back Shay Logan admitting he’d received racist abuse from Celtic fans sparked a nationwide reaction.In the team awards, the Evening Express was nominated for its collaboration with the Edinburgh Evening News following the SPFL’s decision to hold both League Cup semi-finals at Hampden on the same day.

title: discussions to continue over future of charitys aberdeen base
story: An MSP has said discussions will continue with a children’s charity which faces losing its Aberdeen base.Aberdeen Donside MSP Mark McDonald hosted talks at Holyrood yesterday with management of Children st and other north-east MSPs after the charity announced funding struggles.The national charity has said its Aberdeen premises in North Silver Street could close as it looks to “redevelop” the services it provides after losing its core funding from Aberdeen City Council two years ago.He said: “The round table has proved informative and given us all a better understanding of Children’s st’s plans moving forward.“Children st recognise the emerging and changing needs of children need to be met throughout Scotland, and have reiterated their commitment to deliver appropriate support to families in the north-east.“A commitment was agreed from MSPs in attendance to be involved in the ongoing discussions around the role Children st can play in supporting families in the north-east, and I look forward to continuing these conversations with both Children st and local statutory bodies.”Five members of staff are facing redundancy at the charity as a result of the changes.The organisation, which provides hands-on support to meet the needs of families under stress due to a range of issues including poverty, mental health and alcohol or drug misuse, invested £, in its Aberdeen service last year alone.Children st chief executive Mary Glasgow said: “We welcome the interest and support shown by MSPs from across the north-east in the future development of our work to prevent childhood trauma and adversity in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire.“We also continue to have positive discussions with Aberdeen City Council.“Children st remain committed to co-designing and co-producing innovative and sustainable new services with children and families and other stakeholders, including MSPs, and our fantastic local fundraisers and supporters.”The charity previously committed to supporting the children and families in Aberdeen it is currently working with until the end of May. Its Scotland-wide Parentline service, which is already used by families in the north-east, will continue to offer local support.An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “There has been no recent reduction in funding to Children st.“A recommissioning of services delivered by the third sector was undertaken in .“As a result of this, a consortium bid involving Children st was unsuccessful.“At the time of recommissioning, less than half of the referrals to Children st came from Aberdeen City Council’s Children’s Social Work Service, yet it was the only local public agency which funded the service.”

Maybe that has something to do with the enormity of what needs to be done.Once again our hospital beds, services for vulnerable people and other things taken for granted will be in the spotlight.The impact on staff was raised, quite rightly, at the IJB meeting, but there was no mention of the impact on patients and service users.As one NHS staff member at the meeting said: #We can bring forward savings, but what we bring back to the board might not feel very palatable.#There is a need for members of the public to have their say in changes to these public services, and a meeting in Lochgilpheadnext week will be discussing that subject.

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAs a very enthusiastic, though amateur, photographer, I had treated myself to a new and rather expensive camera lens.Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: letters week 12
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,This is a short note of thanks to all who made my th birthday party at Chalmers Court such a success.I did not help a great deal by having a bad fall near the bus stop on my way for the morning papers and am lucky not to have broken bones. A bruised and battered face caused alarm on first viewing which gave way to quite a lot of laughter and bold comment.But what a delightful party, laid on by our warden Sheena Stewart and ladies and saw we all had tea, coffee, and home baking, including shortbread and sconesand presents of wine and malt whiskey. What a lovely morning.To all who sent cards for my th, including the community council, the Wednesday Club, the Inveraray Highland Games , my warmest thanks. And many thanks to those who helped me up after my fall and in particular Stuart Campbell of Brambles who took me to the surgery, whose very kind people cleaned me up and sent me on my way to my party half an hour later.And a mention to Take the Floor too on Radio Scotland on Saturday night. Thank you Inveraray and District Accordion and Fiddle Club and Margaret Mather our secretary for this request.So I won#t forget my th in a hurry, but such kindness and friendliness cannot be forgotten ever.My thanks to you all,Niall Iain MacLean, InveraraySir,I read with great interest the letter in the March  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser from C Rees, Lochgilphead.In addition to all that was mentioned I wonderyour readers are acquainted with the McCrone Report which was written in the s As I’m sure your readers are aware this was when oil had just started flowing from the North Sea. Mr Gavin McCrone was, at that time, a civil servant instructed to write a report on the possible effects of North Sea Oil on the argument for Scotland’s devolution.This quote comes from a letter written, by Mr McCrone, in April : #The Paper was written over a year ago in the weeks immediately before the February  election. This will be particularly apparent on page  where, of course, the ministerial pronouncements referred to relate to the Conservative Government.#So he was instructed to write this report by a Conservative Government but was reporting to a Labour Government.This quote comes from the end of the letter: #When my paper was written it was classied “secret” and given only a most restricted circulation in the Scottish Office because of the extreme sensitivity of the subject.#The report discussed the possibility of Scottish Independence and came to the conclusion: #What is quite clear is that the balance of payments gain from North Sea oil would easily swamp the existing deficit whatever its size and transform Scotland into a country with a substantial and chronic surplus.#Now, this is a very tiny segment from a document that could have changed our history but that’s in the past and we must now look to the future.What is upsetting is thatthis wealth had been invested in an oil fund or more fairly distributed by the  British Government # either Conservative or Labour # there might not, now, be an upsurge in support for separation from Westminster.Wilma Watts, TarbertSir,With Theresa May’s Brexit deal yet again failing to get through the House of Commons and a delay to the date the UK is due to leave the EU, it is clear that we are simply lurching from crisis to crisis.One wonders what good an extension will actually do given the negotiating position of both the EU and the UK. The UK is deadlocked, in terms of its people, Parliament and Cabinet and the likelihood of any semblance of a deal that command the majority of the House of Commons is unlikely. This is especially true given the deep isions within the Tories, both Remainers and Leavers, as well as opposition from the DUP.Given this situation those like myself have long argued that a UK-wide referendum on the deal, a so-called ‘People’s Vote’, with the option to remain in the EU, is the only credible way to break this deadlock. For those who argue that this would damage our democratic process, I am not sure we can slump any lower than the situation we are currently in.As David Davis, the former Brexit Secretary and an ardent Leaver, pointed out before the EU referendum: #If a democracy cannot change its mind, it ceases to be a democracy.#There are few I know who voted for Brexit in the belief it would make them poorer, and it is up to the public to give its view on whether the deal, and more importantly its implications, are what it wants.For once I agree with Jacob Rees-Mogg who previously supported a vote on the renegotiated settlement. A statement he now curiously seems to have forgotten.The Scottish Parliament has led the way in backing a People’s Vote and now that we know the precise nature of the deal, it is up to the public to have its say.Alex Orr, Edinburgh

title: retired teacher unearths marquis family roots
story: Mark DaveyUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowA Bardic family whose Argyll roots date back more than  years is spotlighted in a new book about Highland history.A retired teacher, from Leicestershire, Steve Marquis, has researched his family’s colourful past and unearthed claimed links with Flora MacDonald.The Marquis family history also includes the Jacobite rebellions and Tarbert, Loch Fyne, where his forebears lived for more than three centuries.His grandfather, Angus Marquis, born in Tarbert in , was descended from a long line of Loch Fyne fishermen. He left the village for an apprenticeship at Govan shipyards during the First World War before heading south for Leicester in the s.Steve, , one of several Marquises still living in Leicestershire, has just published The Le and Times of The Marquis Family of Argyll.It covers the family’s long Highland history as bards, smugglers, clan warriors, rebels and fishermen, with one forebear being tacksman on the island of Cara.He was inspired by his grandparents’ lives as exiled Scots, and their tales of Highland le.Though Angus Marquis left Tarbert for a new le in the south nearly a century ago, his children and grandchildren still make summer ‘pilgrimages’ to the family’s spiritual home, tracing the buildings where the Marquises lived and their graves in Tarbert cemetery.‘It has been an interesting experience,’ said Steve. ‘I have been helped in my research by many people and have unearthed details we simply didn’t know about the Marquises who went before us.#There was always an assumption that we were Huguenots, but that appears not to be the case. We were Gaelic speakers whose roots lie deep in Scottish soil.#I discovered that we were linked to Flora MacDonald through marriage, and that our bardic traditions go right back to the s.’Until the late th century, the Marquises were known as MacMarcuis or MacMarquis, and had strong links with the MacDonalds.Angus Marquis was one of the seven children of fisherman Dugald Marquis, born in , who fathered five children by his first we, Margaret Bain, and two # including Angus # by his second, Mary McLeod.While an apprentice in Glasgow, Angus met his future we, Mary Jordan, from Furnace. Together they had five sons, including Steve’s father, George.While several of their offspring now live in America, Australia and Cornwall, most of the Marquis family settled in Leicestershire.The book is available from Steve at: stephen.marquis@ntlworld and there is a website: www.marquisfamilyhistory.

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a £, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr rugby club prepare murrayfield
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club prepare for Murrayfield date with destiny against HeriotsThe club will bid to land a fourth Scottish Cup and complete a league and cup double this season when they head for the capital on Saturday.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  APR NewsAyr Rugby coach Peter Murchie and his players "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Make mine a double, writes Ron Evans.That was the cry at Millbrae when the pink and black faithful realised that their team had created the chance to win the Tennent’s Premiership and the Scottish Cup in what will be the last opportunity to achieve this feat under the current league set-up. Ayr have been there before of course in  when they won the Premiership by defeating Currie then the Cup final against Melrose with the unforgettable Cammy Taylor try in the injury time of extra time. This time, however, they take on Heriot’s in both games. Having won the epic Tennent’s Premiership play-off final against the Goldenacre outfit two weeks ago, the Nailsare again Ayr’s opponents on Saturday in the cup final at Murrayfield. It might be inappropriateto suggest that Ayr are going out to hammer the Nails on Saturday, but that is exactly what they plan to do. Now in possession of more senior cup and league medals than any other Scottish player, veteran full back Grant Anderson told some of the rookies for whom this is a first- time experience: “You think beating Heriots at Millbrae was good  “Doing it at Murrayfield will feel a hundred times better!” Skipper Pete McCallum, heading for his third cup final at Murrayfield with a won one lost one record, certainly agreed that it was great chance for the players to express themselves on the big stage. “Playing on the international pitch is always something really special so we want to enjoy the occasion and go out with a bang,” he said.  As was the case at Millbrae, there will be little to choose between the two sides, their regular league form having panned out with an away win each but in the winner-takes- all contest for the Premiership title showdown, Ayr were superior. “Yes, we are in a good place but there will be no complacency” said coach Peter Murchie. “It was a physical game and we would expect the same in the cup final. “Thankfully we didn’t pick up any injuries and we were able to give the squad a bit of a rest after the last game which has let us build gradually towards Murrayfield.” “The squad are totally motivated as you would expect from any team going into a cup final becauseyou can’t be motivated for that then I donapost know what would get you up for a game. “I have said several times to the squad that opportunities like this don’t come along very often in your career and you have to take those opportunities and make the very best of it. “Some of our squad have experienced this situation before and our senior players will be a big part of what we achieve but we have some really exciting young talent as well so we will give it our best shot and hopefully have a great finish to what has already been a memorable season.” It has indeed been memorable andAyr do add a fourth Scottish Cup success to the Tennent’s Premiership title, then the call will likely be for trebles not doubles all round. Good luck. Good luck.A ticket for the Millbrae breakfast,coach travel and entrance to the match is £.Other options include £ for match ticket and coach travel and £ for the match ticket only. But ticket packages will be available to buy until matchday at Millbrae or at Cafe Ginger and McHarg  Co Accountants in Miller Road, Ayr.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnMelroseAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayrshire support worker struck after
story: NewsAyrshire support worker is struck off after raiding womans le savingsA support worker has been struck off after plundering the savings from someone under her care while employed at Glebe House Care Home, Dalmellington.ShareByPaul Behan:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsJanice Cowan took the vulnerable womens bank card and PIN and withdrew cash on more than  occasions."Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJanice Cowan took the vulnerable women’s bank card and PIN and withdrew cash on more than  occasions. The cash withdrawals took place between July  and May  and Cowan helped herself to more than £, of the patient’s savings. The Scottish Social Services Councilheard how the offence came to light when the victim, known only as ‘AA’ and requiring “multiple care needs” decided to alert care home staff, believing that the money would never be repaid.When shocked senior staff at Glebe House found out about the incidents they called the police and reported the matter to the Care Inspectorate and the SSSC. But in the subsequent investigation, Cowan was understood to have shown “limited insight and remorse” in respect of her actions. The victim gave evidence during the hearing, telling the SSSC’s Fitness to Practise Panel how, during a conversation with Cowan, she told her she was “worried about money.” The victim initially offered Cowan money but that invitation was declined. However, in a later conversation, around a week later, Cowan, who had no previous record of wrong-doing with the SSSC, indicated that she “needed a certain amount of money.” On this occasion Cowan was given the lady’s bank card and PIN and the service user believed £ would be withdrawn. In the weeks and months thereafter, a similar scenario took place “several times.” Several cash withdrawals took place from the ATM at the Co-operative, Dalmellington. Cowan then came up with a “sob story” about a family member’s Christmas present and again, the patient handed over her bank card. This pattern continued and the patient did not report the matter at that point because Cowan “promised to pay it back” and she “believed her.” However, the victim’s concerns grew and she reported the matter to other members of staff after fearing she wasn’t going to get her money back. Another witness claimed she was “shocked” that a carer had taken a resident’s bank card and withdrawn money for her own use. During the investigation process Cowan started to make repayments of the outstanding amount. At the hearing in Dundee the victim was described as a “lonely and vulnerable inidual” but “very switched on” and an “impressive witness” who gave her evidence in a forthright manner and was found to be both “credible” and “reliable.” In their written judgement the SSSC found Cowan’s conduct fell “far below the standards” expected, labelled her actions were “serious and deliberate” and amounted to a “signicant breach of trust.” The Panel also stated they could not be satisfied that Cowan had “acknowledged the gravity” of her conduct, or that she demonstrated “meaningful regret.” The judgement concluded: “A Removal Order is the only sanction that will provide an adequate safeguard against yourepeating your misconduct. “It is the only sanction that will ensure that service users are not placed at risk of harm and will maintain public confidence in social services and the SSSC as regulator.” Cowan was neither present nor represented at the hearing. A spokesperson for East Ayrshire Council said: “We are aware of the situation and understand that care home management acted appropriately in conjunction with Scottish Social Service Council and Care Inspectorate when they learned about allegations against the member of staff. “Through our contract management arrangements we actively engage with all the care homes in East Ayrshire to provide assurance in respect of the quality of service provided to residents.” The Post did contact Glebe House Care Home for a response but did not receive one.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrEast Ayrshire CouncilSocial servicesDundee

title: behind scenes south ayrshire council
story: NewsBehind the scenes at South Ayrshire Council headquartersCounty Buildings mixes antiques with new modern offices in this revealing look behind the scenesShareBySarah Hilley:,  APR NewsCouncillors library at County Buildings "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt is home to antiques, grand paintings and museum treasures. But historic County Buildings is also a modern workplace housing  staff delivering services for more than , people in South Ayrshire. From the grandeur of Provost Helen Moonie’s luxurious sea-view office to the dingy corridors of the basement, the  landmark is full of character. Our Local Democracy Reporter went on a ‘behind the scenes’ tour guided by council depute chief executive Douglas Hutchison. Looking around County Buildings, it is clear to see that history speaks through the detailed decor oozing out of every cornice. Two sweeping staircases sparkle with stunning stained-glass windows which hark back to the time when the whole of Ayrshire was ided into burghs. Each burgh had a crest, which are intricately etched into the glass. They include Ayr, Irvine, Troon Prestwick, Darvel, Kilmarnock, Largs and Saltcoats among others.  Nowadays Ayrshire is ruled by three separate councils but the County Buildings design still echoes a past when Ayr reigned supreme. Its former position of housing the entire admininstrative work of the county is reflected in its extravagant architecture. The main council chambers where all major decisions take place have sleek slide-back oak  – which open into other rooms. The chambers could have one of the finest council views in the country overlooking the Firth of Clyde. Every committee room has an open fireplace, which would have warmed the wind-battered building before central heating. Another room has a glass display cabinet showing a town clerk wig and Royal Burgh of Ayr Truncheon among other artefacts. Councillors have their own swish ‘members library’ with newspapers, tea and coffee. The details of meetings taking place behind closed doors are still written in old-fashioned chalk on the front of blackboards. Showing us around, Mr Hutchison said: “This the front face of the council where the council business takes place.” The director of people also took us to a secret location – a secure vault – which opens into a large room for storingpostal votes.Now there is a mission to make the historic building more up to date to adhere with current workday practices. The original architecture is in conflict with the needs of a al workplace where open-plan is the norm. Attempts to fit more people into open- plan space means walls must come down but due to the listed status of the landmark all alterations must be carefully managed. There is also a need to make room for staff coming from the John Pollock centre and soon-to-be demolished Burns House. In contrast to the splendid offices and committee meeting rooms on the first floor, a newly renovated office for employee services staff features skylights and a purple meeting pod. Mr Hutchison said: “It is a lovely building. But trying to fit a modern working environment into an old building is not easy. There is a lot going on to make it more modern. We need to make more efficient use of space. The days of everybody turning up at their desks are gone. We have to work more flexibly.” Mr Hutchison showed us empty offices stripped bare, which are currently awaiting a facelt. Money to maintain the seat of power is ongoing with windows getting replaced along with other repairs. Mr Hutchison said: “There is a programme of general investment in the building.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsMuseumsKilmarnockIrvineCosmetic surgeryFirth of ClydeTroonDarvelPrestwickLargsSaltcoats
