title: what-it-feels-like-to-be-a-chaplain-for-st-johnstone-fc
story: This is maybe my sixth or seventh season as the chaplain here. Before that I had been at Stirling Albion for a decade so Irsquove been doing this for a while now.Irsquom there mainly to be an ear or a sounding board. Itrsquos more than a social worker as therersquos a pastoral element to it as well. And Irsquom there for all the clubrsquos staff and their families, not just the players and the coaches. Maintaining confidences and trust is key.On a Friday I train with the players. I take part in the warm-up and then often join in with the under-s. I try to keep up with them, although I end up being the ball boy half the time. Irsquom getting old now so itrsquos still a great feeling when I can nutmeg one of the young lads. After that Irsquoll have lunch with the players and wersquoll have a bit of a chat.I usually get referred to as The Rev or Padre. One of the players even calls me Pope. Therersquos a bit of banter too and Irsquom sometimes the butt of their jokes but you just have to go along with that.Irsquom a Christian so that will always be a part of what I do. Many players have no faith or a nominal faith. Sometimes, though, in a quieter dressing room you might get a player suddenly asking, ldquoSo, Rev, what are you preaching about on Sunday  and I then have a right to answer that.Irsquod never go into a group and say, ldquoLet me tell you about Jesus, guys. When a player is injured I donrsquot go up and offer to pray for them. There are times when a player might ask me to do that. But itrsquos not about me preaching. I leave that to Sunday at church.Whenever a new player signs Irsquom over right away to introduce myself. If theyrsquove not had a chaplain at their previous club, they sometimes donrsquot know how to react. Some even stop swearing when yoursquore in their company! But with time most of them realise yoursquore just there to help themthey need it.For the first half-season or so I didnrsquot go near the players at all. I didnrsquot want the club to think I was only there because I was in awe of them. So at the start I devoted more time to talking with the staff and that was great. It got my face known and people became more comfortable with me. And at the start of the second season I had the freedom to go around the place.After month after month of seeing you around, people might come up to you and ask, ldquoRev, could I meet up with you after training in a private place  I want to chat about something thatrsquos going on with my family. And then you help them through those situations.I went on a two-day mental health training course at Hampden. That was exhausting but insightful. It also taught me how to redirect people to get proper professional helpthey need it. Sothere are health issues you make sure they get proper medical support. If itrsquos gambling there are people who specialise in that as well.Irsquove already got a full-time job so donrsquot get paid for being chaplain. This is just my service to the club. But itrsquos a lot of fun, too.Visit perthstjohnstonefc club-chaplainGRAEME MACPHERSON

title: unspun-the-political-diary
story: LORD McConnell was reminiscing about the birth of Holyrood at a breakfast bash organised by thinktank Reform Scotland this week. There was the ldquomad rush to be the first MSP elected won by Tom McCabe, the first speech by Winnie Ewing and the first point of order raised by Dennis Canavan. Jack went on: ldquoSometimes people forget this, but Tommy Sheridan proposed the first private memberrsquos bill. He was a new face in Scottish politics at that time, and obviously went on to-. He paused diplomatically. ldquoTo other things.Island leHOST Chris Deerin also crowdsourced questions on Twitter. A certain ldquoNicola of Bute House asked what Jack could have done to win the  election. Spend more time on party politics, and less on being FM, he said. ldquoI tried to balance the two, but we lost by less than %, by  votes in North Ayrshire or something. Thank you, Arran. Grateful island - not. As Lord McConnell grew up on Arran, presumably the islanders knew him best.Poll: Almost three-quarters of Scots want to keep the poundLoad of shirtJACK also defended wearing his infamous striped kilt and girly blouse at a charity fashion show in the US in . His former special adviser Peter Hastie told the audience his reaction had been ldquoDear God, but Jack said he was ldquoglad people have something to laugh atldquo. They sure do. On the night, he thought it had been a great success. Alas, not for long. ldquoI went to bed in New York and at approximately .am I got a phone call from my we saying, lsquoWhat the f*** is on the front page of The Herald !rsquoCabinet furnitureWHEN Nicola Sturgeon told her cabinet about this weekrsquos big Indyref statement, she received ldquopositive feedback from ministers, her spokesman said. But what sort, panted the Holyrood hacks. Table thumping, cheers, party poppers  The spokesman gave no details. Unspun hears the same question was later put to finance secretary Derek Mackay. Nothing showy, he said. ldquoWersquore too Presbyterian. So no dancing either, then.Web wondersCOINCIDENCE fans have noted that whenever Nicola Sturgeon is moved by the national interest to pronounce on Indyref, her husband, SNP chief exec Peter Murrell, telepathically launches a new fundraising website. In March , when the FM first called Indyref, Pete instantly asked for poundm through ref.scot, and when she reset her plans that June, he started mobilise.scot to ldquobuild a better Scotland. This week, when the FM gave the handle another crank, lo and behold, Pete started rattling the cup again with yes.scot. Cynical  Surely not.Invisible letterNOT that it always go well for the psychic duo. That poundm fundraiser was suspended after massively missing its target. Rather ominously, yes.scot once belonged to Yes Scotland, the losers of . In fact, for the last four years its sole content has been a letter thanking Yessers for their efforts which referred to ldquoaccepting the result of the independence referendum. But funnily enough thatrsquos been deleted.Iain Macwhirter: Therersquos no need for the SNP to take a pounding over currency issueFallen branchFINALLY, Unspun hears of more trouble at the SNPrsquos most dysal branch, Coatbridge  Chryston, base of MSP Fulton MacGregor. Recent minutes state the auditors found more than % of branch spending lacked receipts - a legal requirement - a total of more than pound. The branch next meets on Wednesday. Wersquod gladly buy tickets, but we would need a receipt.

title: scottish-independence-poll-one-in-five-scots-back-nicola-sturgeons-indyref2-plan
story: In a blow to the FirstMinisterrsquos plan for a fresh vote by , only one in five said they wanted to revisit theNo result of  within two years.But the Survation survey for the Scotland in Union group also included far more positive news for the First Minister.It found thatthere was a general election tomorrow, the SNP would win almost as much of the vote as Labour and the Tories combined, and pick up  of Scotlandrsquos  seats.The poll also found  per cent of people want Scotland to stay in the UK, and only % want out of the Union, although the question was couched in terms of Leave and Remain, rather than the more familiar Yes or No to independence.:Nicola Sturgeon jokes she would personally dingy President Donald TrumpMs Sturgeon announced on Wednesday she intended to introduce a framework bill for a fresh referendum at Holyrood, and would ask MSPs to pass it be the end of the year.She said it would allow Scotland to protect its interestsBrexit took place, but admitted it would require a transfer of power from Westminster, a so-called Section  order, before a legally watertight referendum could take place.With the UK Government refusing to grant a Section  order, the Tories dubbed it a ldquobill to nowhere.Theresa Mayrsquos deputy David Lidington yesterday restated the Governmentrsquos opposition at a cyber security conference in Glasgow.The Cabinet Office Minister said: ldquoWe donrsquot see any evidence there is a demand from the people of Scotland for a revisit of the decision they took in . That referendum was something the First Minister and her colleagues said at the time would settle matters for a generation. We donrsquot see that a Section  Order is called for.ldquoI donrsquot see that is going to help put right Scottish schools and Scottish hospitals.Ms Sturgeonrsquos plan was also savaged by former SNP justice secretary Kenny MacAskill, who said anyone who believed it would make Indyref happen soon was ldquodelusional.In an article for the Scotsman, Mr MacAskill said the planrsquos purpose was appeasing SNP activists at this weekendrsquos party conference, who are impatient for action on independence.He wrote: ldquoHolding another referendumrsquos problematic and those expecting an immediate poll delusional. The talk of a poll before  initially sounds positive but itrsquos heavily caveated and restricted by other factors.ldquoWill the UK have resolved its EU position by then  If that has been settled, can a poll even be carried out in time  But it allows [the FM] to reassure the party this weekend that shersquos undaunted and the light undimmed.Ms Sturgeon also announced a Citizensrsquo Assembly to consider Scotlandrsquos future this week.:Scottish independence: How European media reacted to Nicola Sturgeons indyref updateHer Brexit Secretary Michael Russell told MSPs he hoped to publish details of the Assembly and the bill by the end of May.Although Ms Sturgeon said the reason for the referendum was to offer Scots a way out of Brexit, Finance Secretary Derek Mackay refused to rule out pushing ahead with it evenBrexit was cancelled.Asked on Radio Scotlandthe SNP would take the referendum off the tableitsBrexit-based mandate no longer existed, he said: ldquoWhat wersquore saying is Scotland should have the right to choose. We should keep our options open.Ms Sturgeonrsquos official spokesman also refused to discuss the Governmentrsquos plansBrexit was cancelled, saying it was premature to do so, despite the new bill in case Brexit isnrsquot cancelled.The Survation online poll, which surveyed  Scottish adults between April  to , found % of people thought there should ldquonever be another Scottish independence referendum ndash the most popular answer.Another % thought there should be one at some stage but not for at least  years, % said it should be held in five to  years, % in two to five years, and % undecided.Ms Sturgeonrsquos timescale on within two years was supported by % of respondents.Asked how they would vote in a referendum with the question ldquoshould Scotland remain in the United Kingdom or leave the United Kingdom  % said Remain and % Leave.The poll also found % of respondents thought leavingthe UK would be worse forScotlandrsquos economy than Brexit would, while % thought it would be better than Brexit.A further % said it would be no better or worse and % said they did not know.Asked their top three priorities, % said the NHS, % said the cost of living, % the economy, % education, and % constitutional affairs and independence.:UK wont allow second Scottish independence referendum - David LidingtonAsked how they would vote in a Westminster election tomorrow, the SNP was backed by %, Labour %, the Tories %, and the LibDems %.The Electoral Calculus website said the numbers would translate into MPs for the SNP , the LibDems four , the Tories threeand Labour one .Former Labour MP Pamela Nash, the chief executive of Scotland in Union, said:ldquoThis bombshell poll proves Nicola Sturgeon is refusing to listen to the people of Scotland.ldquoIn a hammer blow for the SNP, only one-fth of voters want a isive second independence referendum within two years, and over half say there shouldnrsquot be one for at least a decade.ldquoItrsquos no surprise that support for leaving the UK has fallen to below %, with many former Yes voters changing their minds.ldquoThey have seen how dficult the Brexit process has been and know we are stronger together.ldquoThe people of Scotland want Nicola Sturgeon to get back to her day job and focus on fixing our hospitals, schools and the economy, and to drop her obsession with breaking up the UK.Depute SNP leader Keith Brown said his partyrsquos -point poll lead over the Tories was the largest since , and called it a ldquospectacular boomerang for Scotland in Union.He said: ldquoThis poll has backfired in spectacular style for Scotland in Union, who are clearly running scared of giving people in Scotland the choice over their future. The SNP meets for our spring conference with the wind in our sails, while the Unionist parties continue to languish in the political doldrums.ldquoWersquore -points clear of the Tories as we stand up for Scotland against the damage that their Brexit plans will inflict on jobs and our NHS. Theyrsquove slumped into a dismal third place behind a beleaguered Labour party.ldquoThis poll shows that almost two thirds of people back another referendum and that a majority think Scotland would be better off or no worse off with independence. Thatrsquos a great vote of confidence in the benefits of taking our future into our own hands.ldquoDespite their best efforts in employing a skewed question on support for independence conducted before the First Ministerrsquos announcement this week, Scotland in Union have done us a huge favour.He said this weekendrsquos conference would be a campaign event for the EU elections on May .He said: ldquoThis conference will put us on campaign footing, with a vote for the SNP a vote to make clear that Scotland says no to Brexit.ldquoWith the full powers of independence we can do so much more ndash and conference will debate the economic foundations of an independent Scotland as we build for tomorrow.ldquoScotlandrsquos future lies in Europe ndash and people in Scotland should be given a choice between independence and Brexit.Conservative MSP Maurice Golden said: ldquoNo matter what the SNP says, support for independence simply hasnrsquot risen since the  vote.ldquoThatrsquos all the evidence Nicola Sturgeon should need to take this threat off the table.ldquoBut instead she ploughs on, ensuring Scotland is subjected to yet more ision and uncertainty.ldquoA responsible Scottish Government should be seeking to bring the country together, not drive another wedge through it.

title: scotlands-greatest-drives-part-1
story: What makes it so special  Sweeping bends on a single track road, machair, wildle and walking on the moon.From Tarbert head south on the A towards Leverburgh where the first signs of the unique lunar landscape become obvious. Soon you will reach a small side road branching off to the left signposted The Golden Road, so called because its tortuous route through the intricate landscape of the Bays of Harris made it extremely expensive to build. Before its construction in the s, all traffic between the villages went either on foot or by boat.Head downhill into the village of Miabhaig which is the first of many villages you will pass through. The Golden Road winds and twists through the east coast of Harris, sometimes called the Bays because of its miniature fjords. The single track road connects all the clachans or townships, which have either Viking or Gaelic names.The best part of the route is that it is the bends are almost D and every few seconds the view changes and shows the rough side of Harris. Soyou get to the Golden Road, you see the other side of the island known for some fantastic beaches.As you wind your way along it, at no great speed, you will pass small cottage industries, local artists, crafts and traditional Harris Tweed weavers along with seals and otters relaxing on the seaweed clad rocks. Many little bays are seen on the sea side of the road and old paths are signposted for walks on these vintage ways that were the only ways before the road was build.The mixture of sea, loch, Lewisian gneiss, heather and wet green and little rounded hills makes for a striking landscape as the road winds through lochans with water lilies and bog bean in amongst the lunar rocky landscape. Its like nowhere  in Scotland.Along the way stop at the Tweed exhibition Clograve-Mograver at Drinishader, where you can see the sheds of the weavers next to many houses. The Bays of Harris has enticed many artists over the years who have been attracted by the ever changing light and complex landscape.If you fancy a break, call in at one of a number of galleries along your way ndash some have excellent cafeacutes. Just after the turn off to one of these ndash Holmasaig Gallery at Cuidhtinis ndash the road descends to the shore. Keep following the signs for Roghadal , ignoring any side roads, and once there you will find St Clementrsquos Church, perched spectacularly on a rock.Rodel was once the main town of Harris and the Skye ferry used to leave from here but now it is a tranquil harbour and many ers view Rodel as a perfect ing destination in Scotland.From here head towards Leverburgh and back onto the A towards Tarbert. On the way marvel at Luskentyre Bay, possibly the finest white beach outside the Caribbean and follow the road for the final climb of the day back over the moonscape. So alien is its appearance, the area was used by Stanley Kubrick as the surface of Jupiter in his famous film,  ndash A Space Odyssey.The climb is long and unrelenting, but eventually you will be rewarded with a tremendous sweeping descent back to Tarbert.Pit stop: Various cafes in Leverburgh, including the Butty BusALAN SIMPSONHow long   miles, three-and-a-half hoursWhat makes it so special  Driving into Scotland by the scenic routeLeft, right or middle  Left is the quickest, straight up the Afrom Carlisle . Right, via Berwick on Tweed, you wind your way along the south-east coastline, past Lindisafarne, beaches and caravans and a nuclear power station, which has its own sci-fi charm.But middle is best. Middle is the A. Middle starts in Darlington, runs up over the Tyne and rolls and bumps through rural Northumberland and then begins to climb into the Cheviot Hills until, at ftin altitude, it reaches Carter Bar on the border and suddenly Scotland is laid out in front of you.Ancient Romans, English soldiers, Scottish soldiers theyrsquove all come this way .It must have been a miserable march. But driving it is a rollercoaster of blind summits and stunning vistas and, once yoursquore in Scotland, the delights of Jedburgh and Lauder.If you have the time, detour at St Boswells to Dryburgh to see Walter Scottrsquos famous view.Pit Stop: Try Carfraemill in Lauder at the foot of the Lammermuir Hills.TEDDY JAMIESONThe Cool List:  Scottish golf courses every fan must playHow long   miles,  minutesWhat makes it so special: A scenic coastal drive with points of interest round every bend.This section of East Lothian is being branded as Scotlands Golf Coast ndash starting at the Musselburgh Links, Scotlands oldest golf club, it takes in fine links courses such as Longniddry, Gullane , Muirfield, Archerfield and North Berwick. Watch out for cyclists ndash part of this route is also the John Muir Way.Dont worryyou dont want to pack the plus-fours and the Pings ndash this short stretch has something for all the family. Starting at Musselburgh, you take the left fork down the coastand proceed through Prestonpans . You will quickly pass through Cockenzie ndash now minus the iconic twin chimneys of the recently-demolished power station ndash and Port Seton. Each boasts a picturesque harbour, and the three villages are something of an artists colony, Port Seton being the birthplace of John Bellany.Theres a fine picnic stop at Longniddry Bents, where you can exercise youngsters and empty the dog, before the traffic crawls through Aberlady and Gullane. Take a short detour to see the ruined medieval fortress of Dirleton Castlebefore ending up at North Berwick, where you can take in the beach, some bespoke shops, and marvel at how many xs can cram into such narrow streets.Pit stops: Since this is such a short drive, pit stops are best on thejourney: start with fish and chips in North Berwick and follow it with ice cream from Lucas in Musselburgh .DREW ALLANThe Cool List:  Scottish golf courses every fan must playHow long   miles but it will take all dayWhat makes it so special: Ferries and islands. Five in one day. Thats pretty special.From the ferry, turn right at Brodick and head to Sannox, where the gentle scenery and winding road from the port is replaced by open hillsides and a much faster, sweeping highway, almost devoid of traffic, with the ragged, jagged peaks of Cir Mhor in the distance. Coming down into Lochranza you pass the Arran Distillery and the ruins of Lochranza Castle, which must rank alongside Eilean Donan and Urquhart Castle for its spectacular location.From here, the ferry for Claonaig make its way across the Kilbrannan Sound to Kintyre. Then its along the narrow B onto the A. Itrsquos like a superhighway after the single track: wide, with fast, sweeping corners to Tarbert, with its pretty harbour, like something out of a Katie Morag book. Back on to the ferry, the next stop is Portavadie on the single track before it opens up towards Tighbnabruich and heads for Colintravie. Then itrsquos on to the dayrsquos shortest crossing, to Bute, which takes less than three minutes, then along to Rothesay and onto the fth and final ferry to Wemyss Bay.Some of the roads are poorly surfaced but that doesnt matter. This is a route to take in the scenery, the castles, wildle, lochs and, of course, the sea views.Pit stops: The Sandwich Stop at Lochranza is the perfect place for a piece. They also do artisanal sandwichesand soups and coffees.GARRY SCOTTTornapress to Applecross, Wester RossHow long   miles, around  minutesWhat makes it so special  Hairpin bends and the promise of a seafood feast.It may not seem very far on the map, yet this drive packs a punch, traversing Bealach na Ba ndash a winding, single-track road through the mountains of the Applecross peninsula ndash complete with hairpin bends, jaw-dropping views and plentul nature sightings.Starting from near sea-level at Tornapress next to Loch Kishorn, the road rises to ftin . milesof climbing, reaching  per cent at its steepest gradient. There is a viewpoint at the top with panoramas across to Skye and beyond on a clear day.You may not want to hang about too long as the reward of a hearty feed awaits at the Applecross Inn once you descend the other side.Pit stop: Grab coffee and cake at the Bealach Cafe in Tornapress but save room for a pint of prawns at the Applecross Inn.SUSAN SWARBRICKCircuit from Spittal of Glenshee, Perth and Kinross.How long  Approx  miles, four days .What makes it so special  If you have already driven the hugely popular North Coast  or you are a looking for a quieter destination, the North East  is an ideal alternative for a multi-day driving route.The circuit heads through the north-east of Scotland, visiting the Cairngorms, Speyside, Moray, Aberdeenshire and Royal Deeside. Famous for its drier and sunnier climate, the north-east also delivers with a fantastic ersity of landscapes, from majestic mountains and wild moorlands to glorious glens, rocky coastlines and pristine beaches.The  miles could be driven in one day although that would be missing the point of such a great journey. Instead, four days to a week allows you to stop at numerous attractions, including castles, heritage centres, distilleries, golf courses and nature reserves.A suggested starting point is Spittal of Glenshee in the Cairngorms National Park. Travelling clockwise, day one will take you to Aberlour in the heart of whisky country. There are plenty of visitor sites including two mountain resorts, Glenshee and The Lecht Ballindalloch Castle the distilleries of Glenlivet and Aberlour and a walk to Linn Falls.Day two heads north to meet the coast at Spey Bay before turning east to reach the seaside town of Banff. Mountain vistas turn to rolling farmland and then the fabulous Moray coastline.Spey Bay is famous for dolphin watching, while a string of pretty shoreline villages, including Findochty, Portnockie, Cullen and Portsoy, are recommended for a stop-and-stroll.Take a walk along a section of the Moray Coast Trail and marvel at rock formations called Bow Fiddle and Whalersquos Mouth and visit the atmospheric ruins of Findlater Castle.From Banff, day three will take you to towards Aberdeen for a suggested overnight at Maryculter. In the far north-east corner is the fishing town of Fraserburgh, home to a vast expanse of sandy beach and the fascinating Museum of Scottish Lighthouses. Further south are other highlights, including the natural phenomenon of Bullers of Buchan, Cruden Bay and Slains Castle.On day four, the NE heads west again through Royal Deeside, where the attractions came thick and fast. The castles of Crathes, Balmoral and Braemar beckon, or why not park the car and take a walk into the countryside for yet more wonderful views of hills, mountains and the winding River Dee Pit stop: Treat yourself to a cone at award-winning Portsoy Ice Cream, enjoy a dram at the Quaich Bar at Craigellachie Hotel and dine at highly rated Rothesay Rooms, Ballater.FIONA RUSSELLThe Cool List:The Best Scottish Railway JourneysHow long   miles, around  minutesWhat makes it so special  Steep climbs and sweeping descents.This drive begins with the steady climb out of Lennoxtown on the hallowed Crow Road . As you near the end of the first stretch, it is worth pulling over to enjoy the views for a few moments from what is dubbed ldquothe car park in the sky.Continue up through the Campsies towards the summit and then follow the sweeping road back down towards Fintry. Itrsquos a popular route for cyclists so do take care and give them space.From Fintry continue on the B where you will reach a turn-off and head left for Arnprior or straight on for Kippin.Both routes offer pretty scenery but via Arnprior is shorter as the crow flies to meet the B which runs past Lake of Menteithand Inchmahome Priory. Turn left onto the A and follow signs for Aberfoyle.Pit stop: The Courtyard Cafe, Knockraich Farm, Fintry is home to a coffee shop and artisan dairy. Be sure to try the farm-made ice cream.SUSAN SWARBRICKHow long   milesdepending on the route, allow - hoursWhat makes it so special  Neolithic monuments and stunning landscapesTo be honest, there is no one set route to follow on the Orkney mainland. Rather prepare for a magical mystery tour as you venture off the main roads to scoot along B routes and single-tracks.Head west out of Kirkwall along the A to the junction for the A. From here head north and follow the road in an anti-clockwise direction around the mainland. It is a pretty drive with plenty of points of interest, not least an opportunity is to visit the iron age Broch of Gurness near Evie.The Neolithic monuments at Orkneyrsquos heart ndash Skara Brae, Maeshowe, Ring of Brodgar and Standing Stones of Stenness ndash are within easy driving distance. Built , years ago, this former settlement, large chambered tomb and two ceremonial stone circles form a Unesco World Heritage Centre.On the west of the mainland is Yesnaby with its towering sandstone clfs and majestic sea stack which is a wonderful spot to watch the sunset. Heading south, the turn off is on the right, around a third of a mile before the junction where the B meets the A.No visit to Orkney would be complete without driving over the Churchill Barriers, a series of four causeways linking the mainland to the islands of Lamb Holm, Glims Holm, Burray and South Ronaldsay.Lamb Holm is home to the Italian Chapel, built from two old Nissen huts by prisoners-of-war in . Continue south across Glims Holm and Burray towards the farthest tip of South Ronaldsay and the Tomb of the Eagles, a Neolithic chambered tomb located on a clf edge.Pit stop: Gerrirsquos Ice Cream Parlour, Stenness. Try the monster cone with seven scoopsyou dare.SUSAN SWARBRICKHow long   miles, one hourA bit unusual, this, but it will allow you to indulge your Colin McRae rally driver fantasies ndash albeit at a much slower pace.This forest drive takes you through the woodlands of the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park on a quiet forest road from March to October. Beware, its bumpy going.The route, which costs pound, is one-way and takes you past three lochs ndash Lochan Reoidhte, Loch Drunkie and Loch Achray.The entrance is on the Ajust north of Aberfoyle. There are several car parks on the route as well as picnic areas and short walking trails.Pitstop: The Lodge Forest visitor ventre on the A has a cafe, walks, a shop and also the Go Ape aerial adventure trail. The Brig o Turk Tea Room is a charming spot for a coffee and a cake.GARRY SCOTTDays Out: Scotlands top  beachesHow long   miles, a nice half-hour drive hellip but there are so many places to stop, best leave a full afternoon.What makes it so special  The unexpected, off-the-beaten-track beauty.The sign just past Pitlochry heading north on the A is unassuming ndash "Clunie , Foss " ndash but the road itself is an absolute joy. This little single-track route to Tummel Bridge, along the south side of Loch Faskally and Loch Tummel, takes you to places that you may not have seen before, but which you will never forget. Leave an hour at least to explore the Linn of Tummel ndash an amazing gorge where this grand river is pushed into a series of boiling pots and waterfalls check out Clunie Dam ndash a properly wild feat of engineering at the foot of Loch Tummel stoplong the lochside to marvel at the views.At Tummel Bridge, you have a choice hellip go back to your starting point along the usual, north side of the Loch , or head into the mountains, past Schiehallion and down into Tayside. A real treat either way.Pit stop: Take a picnic hellip yoursquoll be glad you did!ANDY CLARK. The Beatles: Drive My Car DECIDEDLY about more than merely driving a car, as becomes clear from the lyrics: "Baby you can drive my car  Yes Im gonna be a star  Baby you can drive my car  And maybe Ill love you." One of the highlights of the Fab Fours Rubber Soul LP.. The Stills Young Band: Long May You Run, PLAINTIVE tribute, on album by Neil Young and occasional cohort Stephen Stills, about Youngs first-ever car, a  Buick Roadmaster hearse. "Well, it was back in Blind River in   When I last saw you alive  But we missed that sht on the long decline  Long may you run...". The Beach Boys: Little Deuce Coupe FROM the classic album of the same name. "Like many of rocks early artistic statements, [the album] was inspired by a subject of teenage fascination, in this case the hot-rod phenomenon," says Ultimate Classic Rock magazine. Sample lyric: "Well Im not braggin babe so dont put me down  But Ive got the fastest set of wheels in town.". Wilson Pickett: Mustang Sally PICKETTS great version of this classic hit made it into Rolling Stone magazines poll of the  greatest songs of all time. The Commitments recorded it in the early s. "Mustang Sally, think you better slow your mustang down  You been running all over the town now.". The Eagles: Ol  TOM Waits, author of this song, has often spoken about his love of old cars. He disliked the Eagles "antiseptic" version, but that version, with its gorgeous harmonies and pedal steel, deservedly reached a vast audience.. Tom Robinson Band: --- Motorway Great pop single about the joys of night-time driving. "Drive my truck midway to the motorway station  Fairlane cruiser coming up on the left-hand side  Headlight shining, driving rain on the window frame..."Scotland has topped a list of the worldrsquos most beautul countries as voted by Rough Guides readers. Herersquos how to make the most of your trip. Drive slower and smarter. Your vehicle will get better fuel efficiency and emit fewer greenhouse gases by avoiding hard accelerations or slamming on the brakes. Remove heavy items, roof racks and bike carriers when not in use. Check tyres regularly:they are under-inflated, this can reduce fuel efficiency and release more harmful pollutants into the air. Donrsquot let environmentally-friendly habits slip when you travel. Recycle, avoid products with unnecessary packaging and take litter home with you. Eat local produce and support homegrown businesses that prioritise responsible sourcing, manufacturing and recycled materials. If staying overnight consider eco-friendly accommodation such as hotels, hostels, lodges, cottages and cabins with carbon neutral footprints. Stick to the path. If you are out walking or hiking, it may seem harmless to take a short cut off sign-posted routes, but it could be that yoursquore treading unnecessarily through the delicate ecosystem of protected or endangered plants and animals.

title: umi-japanese-cuisine-deanhaugh-street-edinburgh-reviewed-by-ron-mackenna
story: EdinburghOK, itrsquos not quite the Seven Levels of The Candy Cane Forest but for a restaurant the size of a shoe Umi Japanese Cuisine here packs a high level of confusing kitsch into a pretty tight space.Let me put you in the picture. Irsquove bounded down the steps, through the sticky front door and on past the people sitting in what looks like a giant window box with rice paper .Now Irsquom standing awkwardly in a between-raised-tables channel under quaint market-stall roofing while Edinburgh folk look and frown and I swither about whether to go all the way back and pull that door tight shut again. For them. I get it. Itrsquos cold out. Or go on underneath the hanging lanterns, past the fairground-style booth and round a corner into the next room to seeI can find someone who actually works here.Umm, I shut the front door again, properly this time. Then press on towards the Sea of Swirly Twirly Chinese Lanterns and just as I reach the corner a waiter comes running, literally.OK, any speed above excuse me in here looks like running, but he is simultaneously moving and apologising and sitting me at a tiny table which is about the only one in the whole place not under a hanging lamp. And also revealing there are terrible staff-shortages tonight and he has to serve all these peopleby himself. Andhellipwait for thishellipmake all the ramen too.Crikey, I think, looking towards the door. Suddenly itrsquos a very long way away. Too bloody far to run. We establish importantly anyway that there are definitely chefs in the kitchen and I settle in for a long wait. Which simply doesnrsquot happen. Actually, and within, say, a few minutes Irsquom eating from a sweet little bowl of edamame beans and whole chillies tossed in a wok, seasoned with salt and covered with something tasting real good that looks like fried multi-coloured straw.Joanna Blythmans restaurant review: One Square,  Festival Square, EdinburghIs this straw stuff onion and chilli, I ask a waitress who has suddenly appeared to help out. She peers deep into the gloomand announces: itrsquos too dark, I canrsquot see it.Ah, by now anyway Irsquom half way through a pound. six-piece negi toro futomaki, aka seaweed wrapped sushi roll made from ldquothe best part of bluefin tuna tartare with spring onion, shisho and shallots. This from a menu emblazoned with the words: Todayrsquos Special.I have got to say, it does not look like today is this printed menursquos first day in action. Or even close.Whatever, the tuna is plump and pink and pleasantly fresh . And Irsquove been distracted again. Goruden cod finger, made with katai pastry ndash which I thought was actually Greek. This is sitting at the table looking like three giant shredded wheat fingers, one of which is rudely stuffed in a glass of what looks like cocktail sauce but is actually, er, mango mayo. Frankly  Not for me.The sickly mango mayo may just be the accidental reinvention of a Mr Men Yoghurt, and the shredded wheat pastry tastes like fried shredded wheat, and while there is some promised Scottish cod deep inside itrsquos so outgunned by everything  it was pointless even showing up.Fortunately, and just as the remnants of this are being dragged off in shame, my original waiter is back from his ramen booth and is asking what I think of the Crazy Tonkotsu Ramen. Which he just made. Himself.The broth is cooked for  hours, he proudly reminds me, as I slide head-first into slippy, slurpy, soupy-land of pork slices, seaweed sheets and jalapeno strands, all underpinned by a very good, creamily smooth, properly seasoned stock and just the right chilli tingle.Umi Japanese Cuisine then  Mad but definitely not bad. I cant help really liking this place.Joanna Blythmans restaurant review: One Square,  Festival Square, EdinburghUmi Japanese Cuisine Deanhaugh StreetEdinburgh  Menu: Crazy kitschy mix of Japanese staples, proper sushi, interesting ramen, -hour broths and those goruden cod fingers.  Service: Full marks for being honest about staff shortages which actually made no dference as the service was swt, pleasant and warm.  Price: The Crazy Ramen signature dish was almost pound, the excellent shishito peppers pound.. Overall reasonable.  Atmosphere: Frankly, itrsquos a bit mad inside with a multi-level assault on the senses but nothingnot buzzing and busy.  Food: I didnrsquot take to the goruden cod things, but very good ramen and excellent plate of chilli and edamame. Crisp, clean cooking.

title: glasgow-university-unveils-50m-waterfront-campus-on-the-clyde
story: The university said the poundmillion development would be located in the historic former shipbuilding community of Govan on the south bank of the river.Professor Sir Anton Muscatelli, the university principal, said the development could make the city synonymous with innovation in the same way it was identied with shipbuilding and heavy industry in the th century.The Clyde Waterfront Innovation Campuswill act as a centre of excellence for a range of new technologies, co-locating industry and world-class research, and will see hundreds of new jobs located in Govan.: Glasgow University given green light to expandThe main developments will include an enhanced James Watt Nanofabrication Centreand a Precision Medicine Living Laboratory.The JWNC will focus on quantum technology and photonics, enabling the co-location of high-quality academic teams with industrial experts in newstate-of-the-art facilities.The Precision Medicine Living Laboratory hopes to strengthen Glasgow and Scotlandrsquos existing position as a world-leader in the field.The project already has financial backing of poundm from the university and pound.m from the Glasgow City Region City Deal. Further investment bids will bring the total to in excess of poundm.The site for the new campus is currently a disused car park at the southern end of the Clyde tunnel, near the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital.A disused car park in Govan where the facility will be builtSir Anton said: "The universitys plans for investment in Govan are an incredibly exciting new chapter for the university and the city and can be as transformational for Govan and the Clyde Waterfront as our move to the West End from the City Centre was in .: Residents told to expect disruption as Glasgow University expandsldquoAs Glasgowrsquos largest university, we are determined to play a full and active part in the public le of our city and our new campus on the south bank of the Clyde will see even more of Glasgowrsquos communities benefit from our activity.ldquoShipbuilding and heavy industry in Govan and on the Clyde waterfront were the pillars of Glasgowrsquos industrial excellence in the th and th centuries."I have no doubt the innovation agenda and industries like quantum technology, nanofabrication and precision medicine can be to the st century Glasgow economy what shipbuilding was in the past."The campus development comes as Glasgow University outgrowsfacilities on Gilmorehill, in the west end.Dr Sara Diegoli, strategic projects manager, said: "It is in a Victorian building so we have some constraints when it comes to expansion."Professor Dame Anna Dominiczak, head of the College of Medicine, added: "Our current clinical innovation zone will be soon full."Bringing industry, NHS and academia together could put Scotland on the map."Susan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, welcomed the development.She said: "The work being done to regenerate Govan and the banks of the Clyde is key to attracting and developing world-class innovation in this part of the city.A map of the site next to the Clyde"It isnt just about those high-tech academic jobs, its about all the other things that come with it."We are building homes, there will be new commercial and retail units, all sorts of new opportunities are being created."There are also plans to establish invention rooms for use by local school pupils.

title: scottish-independence-how-and-when-scotland-could-rejoin-the-eu
story: She included major caveats, not least Brexit going ahead and Westminster approving a section  order.If there was an independence referendum in the next two years, lets say by the end of , andthere was a lsquoyesrsquo vote, how straightforward would it be for an independent Scotland to re-join the EU and how long might it take Read more: Nicola Sturgeon saysScotland needs indyref to have a choice to avoid BrexitThere are many uncertainties here, including whether, when and on what basis Brexit goes ahead, and how long any independence lsquoorcersquo talks would take between the Scottish and UK governments.If the UK stayed in the EU, it would, in many ways, be much easier for an independent Scotland to then stay in or re-join. The UK, including Scotland, would not have erged from EU laws and regulation, and there would not be any of the border problems between Scotland and the rest of the UK that a hard Brexitmight entail.If Brexit does go ahead, then the challenges will be bigger.On independence, Scotland as a European country would be entitled to apply to join the EU. If there was a lsquoyesrsquo vote in December , then orce talks ahead of actual independence might take around two years or more. SoScotland became independent at the start of , how long could it take to re-join the EU This will partly depend on where the Brexit process has got to.If the UK leaves the EU by the end of , the transition period, where the UK stays in the EUrsquos single market and customs union but without a voice or vote, would last until the end of December .This could be extended by mutual UK and EU agreement until the end of . Butthere isnrsquot an extension, or there was a no deal Brexit, then itrsquos possible that to some extent UK laws might have started to erge from EU laws by the time Scotland became independent.Read more:Mark Smith: What Nicola Sturgeon said hellip and what it actually meantBut,there was a lsquoyesrsquo vote as early as December  i.e. by the end of the initial Brexit transition with the UK still fully aligned, that would give scope politically to agree Scotland should stay aligned to EU rules even while the UK subsequently erged.This would require UK agreement but in the face of an independence vote, accepted as legally correct by both sides, itrsquos not obvious why this would be obstructed.AndScotland was clearly aiming to re-join the EU, the EU would also, from the outside, be likely to recommend Scotland did its best to stay aligned.Given UK-EU trade talks would be under way at that point, the UK would also potentially come under some soft pressure from the EU on thisAn independent Scotland would need to apply to join the EU. The European Commission would assess its application and recommend to the European Council whether to agree to open accession talks.Those talks would cover all  chapters of the EUrsquos rules and laws ndash itsacquis. This process,it didnrsquot hit any stumbling blocks, might take two years for the application and talks and then another two years for ratication of the accession treaty .Read more:How European media reacted to Nicola Sturgeons indyref updateOnce the accession treaty was awaiting ratication, Scotland would have observer status in the EU . And it would doubtless in the meantime have an association agreement with the EU, like other accession candidates.SoScotland became independent at the start of , this analysis means it could take until  to re-join the EU.During this  year period, having an association agreement with the EU would be vital. It would set out Scotlandrsquos relationship with the EU in the interim .As long as Scotland had not erged from the EUrsquos rulebook, relatively rapid accession talks could be envisaged. But there will be substantive issues to negotiate, in particular where the UK had special deals and opt-outs.Scotland is unlikely to benefit from the UKrsquos current budget rebate, so its own budget contribution would have to be agreed in the negotiations.Scotland would also be unlikely to get any opt-out from the euro, so it would have to commit to eventually joining the euro . But the currency debate comes to the fore here.Read more:Greens savage SNPs economic plan for independenceIf Scotland had kept the pound sterling, but the UK was outside the EU, then Scotland would not be able to demonstrate that it could commit to join the euro at some indefinite future point.Nor ndashit took up to a decade to adopt its own currency ndash could it show that as a member state it would use its independent monetary policy to target price stability and make its exchange rate a lsquomatter of common concernrsquo with other member states . So this would be a signicant political challenge.Scotland would be likely ndash as both the UK and Ireland currently do ndash to request and probably get an opt-out from the Schengen border-free zone, in order to allow it to remain part of the Common Travel Area that currently exists between the UK and Ireland.But therersquos no obvious reason to expect the EU to replicate the UKrsquos current special opt-in deal for justice and home affairs issues, where the UK gets to lsquopick and mixrsquo which measures it opts into .Read more:Nicola Sturgeon advisers questions point of new Scottish currencyAn independent Scotland could, of course, decide to drop the goal of joining the EU ndash although this would be a major change.It could decide to apply to join the European Economic Areainstead ndash and accept the democratic deficit that Norway contends with, rather than be at the EUrsquos top table alongside Ireland and others.Keeping the pound would then be simpler on that score. But EEA membership might look more problematicthe rest of the UK did end up in a customs union with the EU .EEA members have to be in EFTA ndash and EFTA members have their own trade deals and cannot, without an exemption, be in a customs union with the EU too.Overall, an independent Scotland should have the prospect of a relatively swt and smooth route to re-joining the EU, subject to negotiating the substantive issues covered above.Read more:SNP hit back as Theresa May claims independent Scotland could not stay in EUThe politics of how the EU member states would look at Scotlandrsquos application to re-join would also be much more constructive, not least in the face of Brexit.Accession would still require unanimity, and the future politics of dferent member states, including Spain, cannot be guaranteed. But, for now, the political reluctance expressed in Brussels in  would not be replicated. And Scotland would be able to develop its bilateral relationships with the EUrsquos member states, as its accession talks proceeded.Itrsquos a two-sided dance ndash an independent Scotland would have to decide re-joining the EU was its priority. And the EU would have to agree it could.Dr Kirsty Hughes is director of the Scottish Centre on European Relations. This article first appeared online titled An Independent Scotland in the EU: Timing and Challenges

title: scottish-question-time-show-moved-to-graveyard-slot-by-bbc-bosses
story: Debate Night will be changed to pm on a Sunday from its slot at .pm on a Wednesday.It was revealed this week that figures fell from around , on its debut in February to around , just one month later.Read more:Viewing figures revealed for new BBC Scotland channelThe move will now see the debate show, which is hosted by Stephen Jardine, up against Match of the Day and News at .Why is there no #bbcdn tonight  Were back after our Easter break in a new slot on the @BBCScotland channel. So please join us this Sunday from pm. https:t.co aFHTGBg pic rzAzYLCdKJProfessor Tim Luck, a former BBC editor, told the Daily Mail that it was clearly not "a vote of confidence" in the show by BBC bosses.He said: "If Debate Night is not yet in the graveyard, it is in intensive care ndash the competition from sport, entertainment and straight news on other channels is formidable on Sunday evenings."Indeed, the most successful Sunday current affairs shows, such as BBC Ones Andrew Marr Show and Skys Sophy Ridge, tend to be scheduled in the morning. Granted, to do that, they would have to call it Debate Day or Morning Debate, but a change of title might be a small price to pay for sufficient viewers to justy the expense."Read more:Jackie Bird leaves BBC Reporting Scotland after  yearsA BBC Scotland spokeperson defended the decision to change time slots, and said the show continues to receive positive feedback.They said: "The switch to Sunday means Debate Night now has an earlier time slot."It continues to receive positive feedback from viewers who value the programme as a forum in which audience members have a say in the big issues and the opportunity to challenge politicians and policy makers."This article first appeared in our sister paper The National.

title: herald-diary-face-the-music
story: A FEW readers told us how much they enjoyed our stories about Vaughan Williams and Edd Grieg last week, so keeping to a musical theme we have looked back at previous Diary stories about bands and singing, including the gallus young woman dancing in front of the band at Glasgows compact King Tuts musical venue who was tapped on the shoulder by a chap who told her: "Youre blocking the view." Hardly missing a beat, she replied: "I am the view.And when red-haired s pop star Toyah Willcox bounced on the stage in Glasgow and shouted: "Glasgow! Ive come for your men!" a woman in the audience merely shouted back: "Take them.A fiddleA READER who ed from a holiday in Venice said he was in St Marks Square when he heard a Scottish voice at a nearby table querying the rather large bill for two coffees. The waiter explained to him that there was a sizeable surcharge for the musicians playing in the background. "If Id known," replied the Scotsman loudly, "that I was going to be paying for the music Id have listened to it.Support actAND a reader in Lochranza once told us about a localwhere there was some stirring fiddle music being played and a woman was askedshe would like to get up and dance. "I cannae," she replied. Then added: "Wrong bra.Knocked upA GLASGOW reader picking his daughter up from a party in the west end reminisced about going to his first party there a generation before. He recalled: "The music was a bit loud, and the neighbour through the wall started knocking on it. I still remember a drunk staring at the wall and shouting, Theres not a door there! Youll have to come roundrsquo."Unorm resultGROWING old, continued. A reader in Bearsden once declared: "I remember in my early s being at a party in the west end when the police arrived saying they had a complaint about the loud music. I couldnt believe someone would complain as it was only one in the morning. Then the other night I was disturbed by loud music nearby at half-past nine and I found myself itching to phone the police.Tied upA LAWYER once told us about an embarrassing moment in court. "I leaned forward to listen to a witness and the spooky tones of a Halloween tune echoed through the court. Whose phone is that  snapped the sherf. I didnt budge as the musical tie my kids bought me faded away in the silence as everyone  fumbled in pockets."Music to his earsWE do like the American acts that come to Glasgow. Country singer Otis Gibbs once told his Glasgow fans: "I had a really nice gig in Cardf. Afterwards a guy walked up to me and said, I want you to know that your music saved my le. I laughed and said, Thats ridiculous, but he said, Its true. I was in a coma for five months and the doctors werent able to revive me. Theyd given up hope. Then one day a nurse came in with a CD player and put in one of your CDs."I immediately woke up, sat up on the edge of my bed, then walked across the room and turned off the CD playerrsquo."Arresting momentAND another American singer, Jace Everett, played at Glasgows Oran Mor, but got lost walking to the venue from his hotel. He went up to a parked police car, explained who he was, and asked where he could get a taxi. Instead the cops told him to jump in and took him to the Byres Road venue. As Jace told the audience: "First time Ive been in the back of a cop car and I wasnt crying.A wash outELAINE Scott, retired manager at the Ben Nevis bar in Finnieston, was once asked in a magazine interview about the famous folk who have called in at The Ben. Her list included Dolly Partons drummer but then she added the memorable explanation: "He was just passing the time while he washed his drawers in the laundrette across the road.

title: poll-almost-three-quarters-of-scots-want-to-keep-the-pound
story: It came as the SNPrsquos leadership urged members to back their vision for independence ahead of the partyrsquos conference in Edinburgh this weekend ndash including plans to eventually move to a new currency ndash amid an ongoing row over the proposals.New polling shows  per cent of Scots want to keep using the pound and only % want to use a new Scottish currency. The question respondents were asked made no reference to independence.However, % said the idea of Scotland having its own currency made them less likely to support independence, with only % more likely to vote to leave the UK. A total of % said they were neither more nor less likely.Read more:Iain Macwhirter: Therersquos no need for the SNP to take a pounding over currency issueThe survey of more than , people was carried out by Survation on behalf of anti-independence campaigners Scotland in Union.It came after polling for the group found only one in five Scots want a second independence referendum within the next two years ndash the timetable set out by Nicola Sturgeon in Holyrood earlier this week.Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said the latest survey revealed ldquothe SNP is not listening to the views of the people of Scotland.She added: ldquoThe overwhelming majority of people in Scotland want to keep the pound and donrsquot want a new currency.ldquoBy remaining in the UK we can keep our pound, protect mortgages, pensions and salaries, grow our economy without extra red tape for businesses, and use a stable currency backed by the strength of the UKrsquos central bank and  million taxpayers.ldquoThe SNP should drop its unwanted plan for a isive second independence referendum and its hated plan to scrap the pound, and get on with the day job of running our hospitals, schools and trains.SNP delegates will be asked to back the partyrsquos Growth Commission ndash its economic blueprint for independence ndash at its conference today.The vision states Scotland should continue using the pound in the first decade after a Yes vote and focus on deficit reduction and curbing public spending.Read more:Nicola Sturgeon facing splits over currency at SNP conferenceHowever, it also recommends a ldquocareful, managed and responsible transition to a new currency once six key tests are met.SNP depute leader Keith Brown and Finance Secretary Derek Mackay have urged members to back the plans, insisting they are ldquostrong, credible and ambitious.But some high-profile figures in the party ndash such as Inverclyde MP Ronnie Cowan and former MP George Kerevan ndash want to drop the six tests and fora new currency to be adopted in the first term of an independent parliament.Robin McAlpine, director of the left-wing think-tank Common Weal, has also urged delegates to reject the Growth Commission, insisting it would ldquofreeze Scotland at Tory spending levels for a decade.He warned the plans risked tearing the independence movement apart and branded them ldquoincompetent, right-wing idiocy.Responding to the Survation poll, Mr Brown called it ldquoanother boomerang attack from Scotland in Union who appear determined to generate more good news for independence campaigners ahead of the SNPrsquos spring conference this weekend.He said: ldquoThis poll shows that a majority of voters agree with our position that an independent Scotland would keep the pound after a Yes vote.ldquoThis proposal is popular with the public and will allow an independent Scottish Parliament to make future decisions on currency.ldquoItrsquos clear that Scotland in Union are rattled by the momentum that continues to build behind the case for Scottish independence.Scottish Conservative shadow finance secretary Murdo Fraser said: ldquoThe Yes campaign messed up the approach on currency last time around, and it cost them dearly.ldquoAnd this study shows the SNP is still no closer to sorting the issue out.ldquoOf course, there is one easy answer to all of this keep Scotland in the union and continue using a world-famous and stable currency.

title: significant-shortage-of-scottish-pork-on-supermarket-shelves-with-german-chains-biggest-supporters-study
story: The National Farmers Union Scotlandrsquos secret shoppers found that it is the German supermarkets Aldi and Lidl that were the biggest supporters of Scottish-labelled pork. A similar exercise in August found that the they were also best at supporting Scottish lamb, will all produce sold being marked Scottish.There was particular criticism forAsda for showing "no real loyalty to UK producers" by sourcing most of its pork for its Scottish supermarkets from outside the Britain and none fromScotland.The  NFUS pork shelf watch, which took in  Scottish stores, found that Aldi were the best supporters of Scottish pork with  per cent from the country.Meanwhile % of pork stocked in Lidl stocked came from Scotland with the remainder coming from EU sources. About half of Co-ops fresh pork was sourced in Scotland.NFUS said there was "signicant scope to increase the volumes of Scottish pork, ham and bacon on many supermarket shelves".There was criticism for Tesco with NFUS saying the supermarket chain continued to "mislead" customers by selling non-British product under its brand Woodside Farm. "providing the impression it is locally produced from a known farm, when it is anything but".Asda did get praise from being close to the top when it came to stocking UK sausages. Some % appeared to be from British pork, beaten only by Marks and Spencerrsquos and Morrisons.:Ten of the most unique Scottish food brandsIdentying Scottish or British produce was, in many cases, very dficult and NFUS pigs policy manager Penny Middleton explained: ldquoThere remains a large amount of co-mingling taking place, with anecdotal evidence of non-Scottish product placed on shelves that were showing saltires above the cabinets.ldquoIn Asda and Tesco, product was very mixed up with pork from several dferent origins completely mixed within the same range and often with very similar packaging, making it easy for shoppers to inadvertently buy product from where whilst thinking they were buying Scottish or British.ldquoFresh pork must all be labelled with the country of rearing and the country of slaughter but our lsquoshoppersrsquo reported finding it dficult sometimes to identy the country of origin beyond simply being reported at lsquoEUrsquo.ldquoProcessed pork products are not bound by the same rules regarding Country of Origin Labelling , but it is required to include COOL where other information on the label may otherwise be confusing ndash such as lsquoWiltshire cured hamrsquo.ldquoThere were plenty of products found labelled with the UK oval health mark of the meat plant that processed the product, but it was very dficult to ascertain the country of origin of the meat. Many packs simply said lsquousing meat from the EUrsquo somewhere in small lettering, so it was impossible to determine exactly where the meat was produced."An Asda spokesman said:ldquoWe always look to offer our customers value and choice and are proud to stock a great range of Scottish lamb in our stores.In ,campaign group Keep Scotland the Brand was launched, prompted by the steady disappearance of the Saltire on Scottish-grown food, and its replacement by Union flag packaging.The #KeepScotlandtheBrand movement has been growing after fed-up customer Ruth Watson began tweeting pictures of Scottish products in supermarkets packaged under a Union flag.This is the NFUSs secret shopper analysis:Aldi: With % of their fresh pork Scottish they are the best supporter of Scottish Pork for the fresh meat category, although it is disappointing that the remainder is made up of what appear to be EU imports, there may be British within this, but greater clarity is needed. Despite being strong supporters in the fresh meat category sadly the same cannot be said for bacon and they score the worst with % of their bacon coming from generic EU sources.Asda: Asda, consistent with previous shelf watch surveys, show no real loyalty to UK producers with very high levels of fresh pork, bacon and ham all coming from EU sources. Credit is due though when it comes to sausages as % of their sausages appear to be from British pork, beaten only by Marks and Spencerrsquos and Morrisons.Co-op: Co-op continue to be strong supporters of UK livestock production with all their meat, in all categories, coming from either Scottish or British sources, with a roughly : split.Lidl: Lidl, like Aldi, do try to support Scottish in their fresh meat range, but fall behind Aldi, only managing to stock % Scottish with the remainder coming from EU sources. They are the highest stockist of Scottish ham though and between British and Scottish they do well on using UK produced meat in their sausages.Marks and Spencer: As expected, MS continue to support UK agriculture stocking only British across all categories. It would be good however, to see Scottish product in Scottish stores. It must be noted however that only  MS store was surveyed.Morrisons: Good support for UK fresh pork, given the history of links with Morrisons and Scottish agriculture it would be great to see ato them stocking Scottish product in Scottish stores. They also do well when it comes to sausages with % coming from British pork, but again it would be nice to see some Scottish pork sausages.Sainsburyrsquos: Good supporters on the fresh meat side, using % British fresh pork, again it would be good to see some identiable Scottish pork in the Scottish stores. With % of their bacon and % of ham all coming from British pork they perform well, but there is definite room for improvement in their sausages.Tesco: Good to see some Scottish fresh pork in Tesco stores and some good Scottish sausages, some small but notable improvements as industry notes that Tesco have started to use Scottish Pork in one of their ham ranges. Steps in the right direction but still with room to improve.Tesco wasapproached for comment.

title: how-women-with-autism-found-shelter-amid-the-trees
story: The teenager had hidden herself away for so long that shersquod forgotten what it felt like to stand outside and feel the wind, to catch a bus for a shopping trip in town, or just walk her dog.Outside, she convinced herself after years of bullying, meant risk and threat. Inside, where no-one could poke fun at her for being autistic, call her names or crush her confidence, was where she felt comfortable.But finally, with a forest campfire blazing, the wind blowing and the sunrsquos rays beating down, the -year-old was finally able to let her anxiety go. Today Jasmine has rediscovered the joy of being outdoors after taking part in a unique programme which encourages autistic woman like her to reconnect with the natural world.Read more:Public urged to view autism dferently in awareness campaignOrganised by SWAN: Scottish Womenrsquos Autism Network and Scottish Forestry, the outdoor workshops cover a wide iety of activities including team building, nature identication and awareness, leadership skills, arts and crafts, and practical sessions such as learning how to build a fire and shelter.By the end, itrsquos hoped participants have the skills to go on to mentor, encourage and support other women with autism.While around , people in the UK are on the autistic spectrum, autism in girls and women often goes undiagnosed: five times as many males as females are diagnosed with autism.One reason is thought to be their ability to successfully hide common traits of autism, others argue the diagnostic tools used to establish autism is geared towards assessing the behaviour of boys and men.The delay or lack of diagnosis means many women and girls may be struggling to cope with autism and without vital support both from professionals and other autistic women.%imageScotland to reconnect with the natural world"Dr Catriona Stewart, founder and chair of SWAN, says: ldquoWomen are often misdiagnosed or misunderstood partly because they may develop coping strategies that can mask the dficulties they face in day to day le, but it is becoming increasingly understood that more women may be on the autism spectrum than previously thought.ldquoThe programme provides an opportunity for autistic women to share with each other their le experiences, learning and insight and to build skills for inclusion and self-development.For Jasmine, diagnosed at primary school and bullied for it at high school, autism had seemed to set her up for a future in which she rarely ventured outdoors for fear of abuse from strangers.Now, having conquered her concerns as a result of the outdoor programme, she is planning to go to university in September and has rediscovered the joy of being outdoors.Read more:How lsquoloveable roguersquo with autism got the help he neededldquoI had forgotten what it was like to be outside, she says. ldquoI couldnrsquot get over how nice the sun felt and how good it was to feel the wind on my face. I loved watching the campfire and just being outside.Jasmine, from Helensburgh, had been gripped by anxiety at the thought of leaving home after experience a dficult time at high school. ldquoI was bullied quite badly, had very bad sensory issues and a complete lack of compassion from my teachers.ldquoI couldnrsquot leave the town I live in without a family member or worker. The whole idea of it was too much for both my mum and I.Her involvement with SWANrsquos mentoring programme and the outdoor workshops helped her realise there were other women with autism who also struggled with ldquobasic and mundane activities, she says.ldquoWe learned about nature and how to be more aware of whatrsquos around us in the outdoors. We also developed practical skills such as putting up a shelter, building a fire, outdoor cooking, and understanding conservation activities. I can honestly say itrsquos really changed my le. I feel much more confident and my self-esteem has increased. I am really excited about things again.Read more:Agenda: How we can help those living with autismLiz Holland from Glasgow, a former Scottish Forestry Volunteer Community Champion, says she has also benefited from the outdoor sessions.ldquoItrsquos excellent to spend time with other autistic women who experience the world as I do, and with whom I can easily communicate and spend time with without unpleasant social expectations being foisted on me, she says.ldquoThe woodlands provide a relaxed, sensory friendly environment, which makes it easier for the mentors and mentees to connect and enjoy themselves and focus on particular activities.Romena Huq, engagement officer at Scottish Forestry, says: ldquoThe outdoors provides a calming environment and plenty of space for people to enjoy but not feel overwhelmed in a group situation.

title: revealed-the-fitness-trackers-that-fib
story: Most of the best and newest devices on the market keep tabsonworkouts, heart rate, stress and everything in-between with pinpoint accuracy.Or do they New analysis from Which  showsthat they are not as accurate as some may think.Their study has exposed the least reliable fitness trackers for measuring running distance ndash with one tracker underestimating the distance of a full miles and yards marathon by  miles.Ahead of this weekendrsquos London Marathon, Which  tests have uncovered the most inaccurate fitness trackers from big brands including Apple, Fitbit and Garmin ndash with the least reliable tracker underestimating distance covered by as much as . per cent.The worst offender was the Garmin Vivosmart , which underestimated the distance of a full marathon by . miles.Which rsquos tests found that when the Vivosmart  tells you that youve run . miles, youve actually gone almost  miles beyond that ndash meaning those training for a marathon would be actually be running around  miles in total.To illustrate the dference in distance covered using the London Marathon route, runners relying on this model would cross the finish line at Buckingham Palace, carry on running south and continue all the way to South Croydon.On the other side of the finish line, a runner using the Huawei Watch  Sport could find themselves around seven miles short of the finish line of the marathon, with Which  finding this model overestimating the distance covered by  per cent.Relying on the Watch  Sport would leave a runner finishing around the  mile mark, or near Canary Wharf in this weekendrsquos marathon ndash the largest overestimation of distance of any wearable in the study. Samsung Gear S, Garmin Vivosmart , Misfit Ray and Xaomi Amazfit BipApple fared relatively well in the Which  tests, with the smallest dference between its most and least accurate models.Of the eight Apple models tested, the most inaccurate was the Apple Watch Series  GPS, which overestimated distance covered by  per cent, or around three miles under the finish line of a marathon. The best Apple model ndash the Apple Watch Series  ndash only overestimated distance while running by  per cent.Which  testing has also shown considerable iations for tracking running distance within brands too, suggesting that buying a fitness tracker from a well-known or reliable brand doesnrsquot guarantee accuracy.Which  said Garmin produced several good models including the Vivoactive , which was  per cent accurate at tracking running distance in its tests.Yet the Garmin Vivosmart  underestimated distance covered by . per cent, and the Garmin Vivosmart HR overestimated by  per cent.Natalie Hitchins, Which  head of home products and services, said: ldquoRunning a marathon is no mean feat, so runners who are putting in the months of training beforehand will want to know their fitness tracker is trustworthy, and not jeopardising their finish times.ldquoOur tests have found a number of models from big-name brands that canrsquot be trusted when it comes to measuring distance, so before you buy, make sure you do your research to find a model that you can rely on.A Garmin spokesman said: ldquoThe Vivosmart  is an all-round smart fitness activity tracker used to monitor wellness, health and fitness for a range of activities."As the Vivosmart  does not incorporate GPS, our recommendation for someone who is running long distances such as a marathon, would be to choose a tracking device such as our Forerunner range which is dedicated to running."A Huawei spokesman said: "Thetest results may y depending on testing conditions such as indoor and outdoor environments and inidual runner iances."With regards to running indoors, as this particular test was carried out on a treadmill, the algorithm of HUAWEI WATCH  Sport calculates the userrsquos stridefrom the acceleration sensor data while running at dferent speed. WATCH Sport tracks the distance by evaluating the data of userrsquos strideand steps. The results may deviate owing to inidual runner iances."Huawei is fully committed to providing accurate and better running experience for users, and we will continuously work to optimize our existing and new generation products."

story: A YouGov poll commissioned by The Times Scotland found that support for Nigel Faragersquos party stands at %, putting it in third place.The SNP has also seen its ratings increase from % in the  contest to % in the survey, ahead of the looming elections for MEPs in the Strasbourg parliament.However, pollsters found support for Labour has fallen to %, compared with almost % in .And the survey suggested that backing for the Conservatives has dropped to %, down from their .% share of the vote almost five years ago in the European elections.The findings ndashnext monthrsquos election actually takes place and the results were replicated at the ballot box ndash could see the SNP having three or four of Scotlandrsquos six MEPs.Elections expert Professor Sir John Curtice told the newspaper that the SNP and Tories would be tied for the final MEP place in such circumstances.The outcome could also see Labour drop from two MEPs to one while the Brexit Party would pick up the other seat, The Times Scotland said.The poll also recorded growing support for Scottish independence, with % of Scots preparing to vote Yes, compared with % in YouGovrsquos poll for the newspaper last summer.The findings were published days after First Minister Nicola Sturgeon told the Scottish Parliament there should be another vote on Scotlandrsquos place in the UK before the next Holyrood elections in May .YouGov interviewed , people on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday this week.
